												In short i spend 2600 hours in this game (2 years) and never regret buying and playing it -Awesome game, awesome campaign!! -Brings WH40K to life-Buy it if you love tactical RTS or just a WH40K fan...its totaly worth itThe Long Version~Welp been a fan of WH40k for awile now and still is. As you can see the 2600 hours that i played this was one of the longest games i played and if you like more tactical and up close RTS rather than mass production and watching everything explode, then this game is for you.In my opinion they also improved alot of the Warhammer 40K models/characters to look more badass, Space marines look more heavy/bulky and...well they just made every faction look more believable and cool looking compared to DOW1In terms of following lore they did try their best and improved alot compared to DOW1. but really how can you balance things in a legit game when 1 Marine has the potential to take out a small army in lore wiseIts a good game.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Most people know what this game is about. The store page is pretty accurate in describing what it is.Is it good?Depends. Some people enjoy making a massive army and steam rolling the enemy. Others enjoy having a smaller amount of units and managing them using their unique abilities. If you fall into the second of these two, then give this game a go. If you prefer large armies, I'd say pass on this.The Warhammer 40k universe is incredibly well presented in this game. The gameplay is mostly focused on smaller squads and managing their abilities. The combat is great with it's array of animations (which you can catch repeating a little too often sometimes) and solid sounds to back it up.The single player campaign is good, although I think most people will be attracted to the multiplayer more than the campaign.What I would add to this game if I could would be to add more races (I miss Tau and Necrons) and have more maps to play on.A solid buy if you enjoyed previous DoW games. Just be aware it does differ from the first and although the addition of Tyranids is awesome, they've left out other races.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2015
												When Dawn of War II came out, it was an absolutely groundbreaking title. It offered some of the most competitive multiplayer at the time, and the later addition of The Last Stand mode offered hours of entertainment to both casual gamers and pro-players alike.Now, if in 2015 the size of the multiplayer community has dwindled only to a fraction of what it was, you can still find other players out there (steam forums help in this regard) and enjoy some good games, or just plunge straight through the campaign.Dawn of War II was worth every cent at the time it was released. As part of a Steam Sale, however, there's no reason for you not to pick this up and give it a go. Especially if you're already  fan of the first Dawn of War, or just appreciate the universe of Warhammer 40,000 in general.

content:
Posted: May 29, 2015



YouTube™ Video: Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War II Review 

			Views: 692,089		

			Relic conquers new territory with its hybrid-RTS sequel.		

Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War II is the next installment to the critically acclaimed Dawn of War franchise. It was developed by Relic Entertainment who has done a fine job handling the series with respect and care, and giving the Warhammer 40k universe justice.Dawn of War II is a Real Time Strategy game set "in the grim darkness of the far future" on Games Workshop's popular Warhammer 40k tabletop universe. The player will take on the role of a Blood Raven Force Commander who leads a small task force in a desperate attempt to save one of their last few remaining recruitment worlds from the destructive power of the Aliens who seeks to destroy it.


YouTube™ Video: Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War Review 

			Views: 43,093		

			Greg Kasavin reviews the real-time strategy game based on the Warhammer 40,000 universe. "Dawn of War is a testament to what can be so great about real-time strategy, and it captures the grim and...		

PROS:+ Good Visuals: -The game could have used better textures but it still looks nice as it is. Combat animation and movements are great which complements the very well done character and unit models. The game should be 5 years old by the time this review is made, but it has that kind of visuals that ages very well.+ RPG Type Campaign: -Also a CON (see below). Although the Dawn of War games are known to be a Real Time Strategy Game, this Dawn of War II's Single Player Campaign mixes an RPG element into it (character progression and wargear customization). The original RTS formula is not lost however, because the Multiplayer experience, whether against players or the AI, is still a traditional RTS experience.+ Wargear and Character Progression (Level Up): -There is an healthy amount of drops and loots in this game which works well on different combinations and situations. This vastly increases the re-playability of the game since the player may experiment with different character builds with different items to attain different results in their missions. This is specially true on the harder difficulties.+ Variety in Difficulty: -Single player offers a good choice on difficulty by having a fun and satisfying normal mode, and a very brutal higher tier difficulties for players who like to challenge themselves in fighting notoriously hard game modes.CONS:- Path-finding Problems: -I noticed that some of the unit's individual AI have a hard time grasping orders. They sometimes run out of cover, charge the enemy even though they are given specific orders for range combat, and even sometimes get delayed response to orders like throw grenades or bombs despite being in range.- RPG Type Campaign: -Some fans of the old games might not appreciate the RPG element since what really made the original Dawn of War games fun for them would be the base building, management and troop training rather than squad based tactical combat.- Recycled Maps: -Map variation in both Multiplayer and specially Single Player is woefully lacking with a majority of maps repeating on missions. Company of Heroes, a game developed by the same studio and using the same RTS principles, had more map variety and originality and it was released 3 years BEFORE Dawn of War II.CONCLUSION:With its flaws its still a good addition to the Dawn of War franchise. Although it has deviated from its original formula of a traditional RTS in favor of a more RPG-esque single-player experience, I can still say that I found it fun.

A Screenshot of Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War II

content:
Posted: September 23, 2015
												3 Awesome and largley different game modesCampaign > control 4 squads, level up, find better Loot. You arent stuck with the same 4 squads either as they can be swapped for others ( dont like Scout marines, no problem, Dreadnaught?), some interesting boss battles aswell. Last Stand > 3 player controlled heros must survive against hordes of enemies, 20 waves with special boss waves, fight the Eldar , Space Marines, Imperials, Tyranids , Orks and Chaos. Level each Hero to 20, unlocking more gear as you level, Play as An ork Mek Boy, Space Marine, or Eldar Farseer. Multiplayer PVP or Ai > Small scale warfare heavily focused on tactics and stratergy, an example of what it can be like is 'Avatar of Khaine is very strong but a good opponent could kill him with a handful of troops if he isnt supported', each race can choose between 3 commanders, eldar for example can have a Seer Council Warlock, Farseer or Warp spider commander, Each commander has its own wargear to purchase in game. All modes are enjoyable, and the game is very well made with a great ammount of detail for an RTS, that being said , last stand and campaign double up as RPG games, I often feel like playing them if I want a change from Torchlight 2 or something similar.  9/10 would highly recommend. - Con - more could have been done for people who play the game offline, a lot of newer games seem to be very restricting to people who don't want to be online, this is no exception, although The campaign and PvsAI alone is solid enough to merit its very reasonable price tag.

number of helpful: 62 of 66 people (94%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 23, 2015
												Dawn of War II is a science-fiction real time strategy game based in the Warhammer 40k universe.    When most people think of RTS games, games such as Starcraft and Warcraft typically come to mind. You have workers to build up your base so that you can train more powerful soldiers. Resources must be harvested, but there is a finite amount of them. Indeed, this is how the first Dawn of War functioned.  However, the sequel takes a much different approach.     In the single player campaign, you are given 6 unique squads, and 6 only, to take on missions. No base building whatsoever. These squads can be upgraded with weapons and armour, and can level up to gain bonus abilities. It is a extremely well-executed combination of an rpg and a rts. The story is fairly linear, but you are free to explore the planets and do side missions at your realative leisure (that is, until the space bugs show up. Then you need to be quick or else the bugs will eat the planet).     The multiplayer is also a genre-masher. Each race has three different "heroes" which act similarily to champions in DotA or LoL. They level up, can be upgraded, and can oftentimes turn the tide of a battle. All of your other units are spawned from you one and only building, so if it dies you're out of luck. There aren't any workers, and you must collect resources by capping points. A capped point will grant you the resource constantly. The more points you have, the more resources you'll consistently obtain.    The other huge change in DoW II is the "Last Stand" game mode. Three players, each controlling one of the heroes, must survive wave after wave of enemies (top-down horde mode pretty much). You're heroes level up, get more powerful, and eventually die because Last Stand is hard.If you enjoy RTS games, but are tired of the same-old same-old style that most RTS's follow, then I would recommend this game (or DoW II: Retribution the stand-alone sequel).

												This is one of my favorite games I highly recommend it! The campaign is very good and engaging, you can also do coop campaign with a buddy, 2 squads per person! The visuals are very good and so is the sound quality, if you have a good sound system or high quality headphones it really stands out! 												If you're new to the DoW fanchise you might like it, but if you're a returning player ehhh...The game is in no way bad, but if you've played the previous DoW games(Dawn of War, Winter Assault, Dark Crusade and Soulstorm) you most likely won't want to waste your money. Posted: May 9, 2015
												I'm a big fan of Warhammer 40k and strategy games so I couldn't miss this one. Story isn't much entertaining in this Dawn of war II series, but the gameplay where you lead 4 units and use tactics in order to defeat your foes (orcs, eldars, chaos, tiranids) who highly outnumber your forces is much more challenging and enjoyable. Game offers you coop option in campaign, where each of you controls two units, this is huge plus for DoW II, makes it even better and also playable on master difficulty.Game has few multiplayer mods, but with only a few players playing this game, its almost impossible to start MP match. At least some people still play The Last Stand mode, which is for me the best part of this game, 3 players in the arena fighting against enemies wave by wave. i think this game was meant to be played mainly in multiplayer but it didn't work that way. I recommend this especially for its coop campaign, worth to give it a try. 7.5 / 10

Posted: August 9, 2015
												"Dawn of War 2" is a very good game, though not necessarily the flagship achievement of the RTS genre. Part of the real-time strategy fans who like expanding the base and microeconomic management will be disappointed almost complete elimination of these elements. In exchange for material management we get a game filled with action, centered on the optimal use of units and requiring deal of intellectual effort on a par with good reflexes and tactical complex management situation. Cons of game, repeatability campaign missions and a small number of maps, does not change the fact that is a very polished product worth recommending to every lover of RTS.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												While fun this game doesn't manage to hold my interest like Dawn of War Dark Crusade or Soulstorm. I am also loathe to call it an RTS because it departs from all of the core bits of that game type. There is no base construction at all, or unit construction. What it DOES do well is act more like a real time adaptation of the tabletop game. You command 4 squads on a map to take on various objective. Which squads you take are up to you, within the ones the game makes available, and you can go after 1 optional objective per run. Missions are scored by how you do on several factors, the better you do overall the more XP your squads get. As you level up your squads you can customize their skills and gear. The story is fairly engaging and the voice acting doesn't suck, but also feels like they tried to appeal to a more generic audience than a hardcore Warhammer 40k fan. Really it feels more like strategy roleplaying game and less real time strategy.  3 out 5 stars imo. Definitely worth it on sale.edit:and immediately after I post this the game decides it is going to refuse to launch for any reason, files verified as ok just stuck forever at 'preparing to launch' then it did even more weird things. Uninstall time

content:
Posted: March 4, 2016
												In the grim dark future of the 41st millennium, my imaginary OCD compels me to begin every 40k review with "In the grim dark future of the 41st millennium".Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War II is, as you may have guessed, a sequel to the popular Dawn of War games. However, it's very different. Basebuilding is nonexistent, you can only have around ten squads or vehicles, and the graphics look better. This is not to its detriment - the small scale of this RTS makes it much more tactical. The Eldar are also far less overpowered, so this is a plus. You gain resources by capturing requisition points and power nodes on the map. The HQ can be upgraded to gain more powerful troops. Squads can only be reinforced when near the HQ. This game is, so I'm told, much closer to the original tabletop than the first Dawn of War.In the campaign, you have four squads of space marines each led by an important character who levels up, gets wargear, et cetera, which gives it an interesting RPG aspect. And yes, I said "space marines", because they're the only faction you get to play as in the campaign. Moving between planets does have a great loading screen, though - you see a fleet of Imperium ships shoot off into the Warp.Another feature, although this is common to all Dawn of War games, is the army painter - for the fashion designer in you! It brings the whole "custom army" appeal of the tabletop to the PC, albeit in a much more limited form.There are only five factions in the game. Space Marines, Tyranids, Orks, Eldar, and if you get the expansion, Chaos. Space marines are generalists, Tyranids are basically Zerg (to be more accurate, Zerg are basically Tyranids - 40k came first), Orks have strategy that can be described with the word "WAAAAAAGH!", Eldar are the gorilla geurilla warfare guys, and I don't know what Chaos does. Dawn of War II's Chaos army seems to be somewhat Nurgle-focused, from what I've seen of other players.While some complain about how it's not enough like Dawn of War, it's still a great game in its own right. If you like 40k, I highly recommend this game, since it's great for short battles. The campaign does leave much to be desired for us non-Space Marine fans, though.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												This the review of the righteous! Fear its divine power!If you're looking for incredibly zealous outcries to inspire your daily actions, then this is the game for you. Dawn of War II is the sequel to the original Dawn of War and all its expansions and it delivers in spades. For starters, this game is built on the rich lore and backstory of the Warhammer universe. After their disasterous defeat on Kaurava, the Blood Ravens are down to but a single star sytem from where to recruit their new members to fight in the Holy Emperor's name. One problem; the Tyrannids are coming and they have an appetite for planets and everything that lives on it. You control the Force Commander. A nameless, and voiceless avatar who leads a small taskforce from planet to planet to stop the Hive Fleet before it devours the precious planets of the aurelia system. Contrary to the original Dawn of War, this game is focussed on tactics rather than strategy and plays out on a much smaller scale. Instead of base building and massing armies you control up to four units, each with their own abilities and weapons. The game also introduces an RPG element that allows you to customise your squads with new armour, weapons and other items to smite the enemies of man. It is therefore such a shame that there is only one campaign to play. This game offers four different races to play as, but does not allow you to play them in the same narrative context as the space marines. That said, this game's campaign is no slouch. It is a fully realised story with stellar voice acting accross the board. If brawny men with zealous convictions are not your thing, then you better pass on this pack of awesomeness. Unfortunately for you, there are no other reasons to not get it, so what are you waiting for?

Posted: May 3, 2016
												To this date, one of my favorite games of all time, made at the pinnacle of an era now past when companies released complete products to loyal gamers, and when "DLC" usually meant a comprehensive expansion pack with hours of additional content. The music, the animations, the graphics, the story, all, one after the other, on point. The mix of RPG-like elements with strategic RTS combat, on point. The limited base-building options forces you to be aggressive and punishes "camping." 10/10 with all expansions.

Posted: November 17, 2014
												I want to start out by thanking Sega (and Relic) for providing replacement keys for my entire Dawn of War series, years after I had purchased and subsequently lost access to the games. So big "props" to them about that!As I have mentioned before I am a big fan of the Dawn of War series, and I have played most of the games. Dawn of War 2 and Dawn of War: Dark Crusade are probably my favorites out of all of them ( I have not played Soul Storm, Retribution, or Chaos Rising).  I like the Direction Dawn of War 2 went with the single player Campaign, and have enjoyed it a good deal. I am also a fan of the multiplayer of course, but I have got to note I am really liking the Last Stand game mode alot!I am hoping Sega ( and Relic of course) sometime in the future further the franchise with another Dawn of War game. We Warhammer fans dont get enough "good" games. I have got to say if you are a fan of Warhammer, RTS games,   Sci-fi, or any genre in thereof it would be a shame if you did not look at the Dawn of War series. It may seems a little confusing at first with all of those stand alone expansions, but if you have read this far into my review, do it. Go look at them I am sure if, like I said above, you like any of those genres I mentioned there will be something in these games you will enjoy.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												I thought it wouldn't be as good as the old one... it wasn't, it really really wasn't.I PERSONALLY found the story kinda of boring and the gameplay dull, the guns had no real impact and the repeditive nature of the maps for every missions was nearly the same, kill all the enemies then go after the boss and it took to long, Xcom knew how to do squad combat.It also pushes a story that is hard to care about, the same could be said about the characters that it tries so hard to push on you.It does have interesting defensive missions but that the only time where the game came to life for me. However, the resources you where defending where completely usuless to the actual gameplay, the arena was an interesting idea but I didn't care for it. I missed the base building where you could create an army where you could actually flank and use actual army tactics, yes the old one had its mistakes but it actually felt like you could build an amry and have massive, exciting battles. Even in the skirmish mode where you are meant to build armys it takes far to long and the battle generally goes back and forth and comes off as boring, with no obvious units that are clearly meant to be used agaist others and even the ones that are useless for the task they were intented for. The campaign in no way prepares you for skirmishers and multiplayer with completely different rules appling for the each type of game mode, I know there are meant to be differences but I feel that there is too big of a gap and so puts people off playing the other game modes. So yea over all point, this is not the amry building game that it claims to be, expect small squad combat that is slow and tedious where you mircomanage your squad. You can do better than this game, my advise play the older one, as I said before they have plenty of mistakes but are a hell of a lot more fun.

number of helpful: 16 of 16 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 17, 2016
												This review is only about Dawn of war 2 singleplayer campaign.Gameplay is very straightfoward and fast. There are wide variety of abilities and units you can select to slay your foes. Different enemies requires different tools of the trade. There are so many mixes you can combine with available items and abilities that game keeps interesting for a good time. Although 10 000 slayed orcs later you feel like you have seen it all. Boss fights are disapointing as every boss just takes 1 000 times more dmg than average unit and launches some special blast at a pre-marked zone. Bosses gets repetive really fast.Main plot and characters are well written and fits perfect to wh40k's rich lore.  I like the idea that you simple don't have time to do every mission there are available. You have to excecute missions that suits your overall situation best. Also there are usually 2 strategic assets on the map and you can only conquer one of them. There are 3 kind of strategic assets in the game each benefit different kind of boost to you. Choose the ones suits you game style best.It would have been much better if you could just upgrade your weapons with points that you get by completing missions. Now you have to constantly check dmg/stats about weapons that drops during missions and you get like 10 new weapons in every mission. Useless weapons (about 90% of all drops) you just destroy to get small amount of experience points. All this dazzling doesn't bring anything good to the game and this mechanic should have been simplyfied. CGI cutscenes looks outdated and they should have done them with live action like in wh40k: Final liberation (1997). World of warhammer 40k is still well represented in cutscenes and especially in the opening cinematic.Endless slaughter what this game offers goes really repetitive after you have seen all the type of enemies and weapons there is to see. This game is without a doubt recomended if you are a warhammer fan, as you get so much more out of this game if you know the basic settings in warhammer 40k universe. The game kind of assume you are familiar with the lore and goes straight to the "Bom bom bom" -part.10 - Perfect game9 - Excelent game, best of the genre8 - Good game, worth your time7 - Average game, nothing really special6 - Bad game, avoid5 - Painful to play, completely waste of time4 - Failed game, unpayable

Posted: September 25, 2015
												A lot of things have improved from the original Dawn of War. Now the UI is cleaner. You can easily navigate around during the heat of the missions.The only minor grip is that you can't really hear the voice acting too well during the mist of a heavy firefight. What's funny is that once the battle is over with it goes from low sound to high sound in an almost instant. There is also the issue of lack of saves unlike the original one. This game offers online co-op which is cool. The details are much more improved since the last game. Although, some of the last game's mechanics seem to be more "needed" here rather than just the one game.All in all it's a good Warhammer game.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												Dawn Of War II is easily one of the best real time strategy games out there. For me personally, it easily beats Starcraft 2, as far as the singleplayer mode is concerned, though. It has a brilliant mix of strategy and light RPG elements that all work together quite nicely. Find some random loot, give it to one of your units and you're all set to kill those damn orcs. It adds a certain layer of personalization. Plus, there's quite some loot to be found so there's always an incentive to explore the levels.The levels are set up with a cover system. Green means you get the best cover for your squad and yellow is 50/50. You actually have to set up your units carefully and not rush them towards the objectives. They'll only get killed. You *have* to use the cover properly in order to survive some of the tougher levels. Some of these levels even end with a bossfight, which are epic and awesome, even if they're not all that focused on strategy, but more on action.The graphics are, even to this day, beautiful and colorful. Just don't zoom in too much. The voice acting is also still solid.Now the story I can't remember so that hasn't made such an impression on me. But I admire this game for trying to bring new stuff to the strategy genre. It was really in need of some new and fresh ideas. Relic has done this beautifully.About the multiplayer; I must admit that I haven't really given that a shot, but the survival mode is addictive and hard. I've played that for hours and never once got bored. I don't think any other game before Dawn Of War II has ever introduced that, for the RTS genre that is.As of this day I'm still waiting for that Dawn Of War III announcement. Just don't make the same mistake as with Company Of Heroes 2, Relic. Make it refreshing and new once more, just like you did with this gem of a game.Highly recommended ![Rating: 92/100]

content:
Posted: June 11, 2016
												The old DoW was a basebuilding RTS game ala Starcraft, and it was FANTASTIC... this is NOT the same game, however, it is very in it's own right. Almost all the negative reviews are due to the fact that the core game mechanics have changed, and in my opinion, these negative reviews would likely not have even cropped up had the title of the game been something other than Dawn of War. Being a sequal, people expected more of the same with a few enhancements, instead they got something totally different. Pros:- Decent Graphics for a RTS even today... the animations are a lot of fun.- Great Micro gaming! If you are into Microing your units in RTS games, that is what the focus of this game is. You can pull off some really cool combos and tactics in this game, especially given all the different types of gear you can combine with various skills.- The game is fast paced, bloody, and ultra-violent. It IS true to the name WARHAMMER. - There RPG aspect of the game is pulled off very well, swapping up your team with various skills and loadouts really changes the gameplay. It's very fun to try new tactics and ideas.- The star map and mission selection is cool. Sometimes you will have to pass up on a mission to persue a different one and there are reprecussions for your actions. Let a territory fall and you may lose some of your orbital support in the sector, but maybe it was worth it to get that blue legendary reward from the other mission. You can always comeback and reclaim the territory later with bigger better gear. - The balancing seems pretty great. For every unit there is a counter, this includes bosses. Take heed to the tips before the missions as they will potentially let you know an enemy's weakness, or give you reports as to what the enemy is bringing to the fight so you can adjust your loadout appropriately. - You feel like you are getting stronger throughout the game, and some of the end-game weapons and skills are great!- Multiplayer is a lot of fun- reminds me of some of the greates Starcraft1 RPG mods.- A ton of content. I haven't even touched anything other than the base campaign, and then I get to play Chaos... after that if I'm still binging on the game Ill check out the DLC, but you get a LOT of content with just the base game. Cons- Towards the end of the campaign the game begins to get a bit repetitive. - Same maps are reused a bit too much. The maps are great, wish they had more.- Sometimes the pathfinding will drive you insane. Multiple times Ive lost a team because I told them to fall back, and they do so by charging straight into the enemy to go around the long way. Very irritating sometimes. - Level Cap at level 20 seems to come a bit soon... I want to keep progressing my heroes!- The inventory screen could use some filters. Things tend to get a bit muddled and cluttered as you collect more gear. Also, while the character screen shows base stats, it would be nice if it displayed other bonuses given by your equipment (resistances mainly... many different pieces of equipment will boost resistences, but you can only see this when you hover over the items).- Some of the bosses are kinda lame, while others are pretty awesome with their own unique tactics which can take you by surprise at first. - Multiplayer is dying out. hopefully there will be a greater player base with the announcement of DoWIIII think using the systems built here they have a great formula, and perhaps a different Warhammer franchise of games altogether. I'd love to see the same mechanics expanded upon in another game... BUUUT I also want to see another PROPER sequal to DoW. I enjoy both in their own ways. So, looking at the game in a different lens of NOT a base building RTS, but a tactical squad command game, I would highly recommend it 8/10.

												My first steam game, yet still my favorite game. Dawn of War II is really different of Dawn of War I, as you don't have to build buildings anymore. Instead, you get to play with a few squads, which you can level and upgrade like heros, in the campaign. The skirmish is quite the same, except that you have to choose 1 hero, and you have only 1 building (the HQ, which can produce units). If it gets destroyed, you lost. And then you have The Last Stand, which is by far the best DOW II game mode. Pick a hero (Farseer, Mekboy, Space Marine Captain), join forces with 2 other players, and then survive through 20 waves of enemies.

content:
Posted: March 29
												This review will be focusing more on the Campaign rather than the other features of the game.As a Warhammer 40k fanboy, I'm gonna write a passionate review about this game and share some of my experience, because honestly, this game deserves my everything.Ive played over hundreds and hundreds of video games, finished all of their singleplayer campaigns, but never has finishing a campaign felt so satisfying to me till now...The campaign of Dawn of War 2 is just incredible to me, I'll count the Pros and Cons to it.Pros:-Great character customization. You level up your squads with the XP they gain in the battles. It has a really good skill tree for your squads, and you have the choice to make a specific squad more damage wise or more support wise, (there is a skill branch for Health, Ranged Damage, Melee Damage and Energy).-Great story. Honestly, the story of the game surprised me, its incredible, you will actually care about the characters, and there are some moments in the game when you'll be like ''oh my...'' and I'm not even going to mention the last mission in the campaign, it litteraly made me SCREAM and gave me a ton of goosebumps from how exciting it was and how epic it was.-Pretty cool campaign concept, you will be able to travel beetwen 3 planets (Calderis, Typhon and Meridian) which all have diffrenent enviroments.-The Characters. Are. Just. BADASS. Seriously, the main characters are just awesome, they all have diffrenent personalities and just say some pretty awesome lines that will be stuck in your head for a while. The other characters such as the Orcs are just funny as hell, I dont think I mannaged to NOT laugh when I heard the Orcs speak, they just say the most hillarious lines ever... an example: ''ITZ DEM HUMMIES, FIGHT 'EM YA GIT''. -Freedom of play. The campaign has side missions in the campaign menu which you can go and do, most of them are missions such as defending a building, or killing some xeno commander. -Tyranid infestation. I think this is an interesting thing they added in the game. Tyranid infestation is a system, where the planets in the game, get infested by the xeno Tyranids. How much the planets get infected, depends on how you play the game. If the Tyranid infestation bar reaches to max on a specific planet, you'll be having a harder time dealing with them on that planet.-THE CAMPAIGN HAS A COOP MODE. Well thats all I'll say about the pros, believe me, there's a lot more things about it that makes it glorious, but the review will be too long. So here are some of the cons Cons:-It can get a bit repetitive during the end. I'll be honest, during the last moments of the campaign, you'll be doing 3 or 2 missions that are basically ''go and kill that Tyranid boss'', which can feel a bit repetitive in all honesty, but it isnt a big issue because thats a very small portion in the campaign and you'll forget about it once you reach the final mission.-Disconnects from the campaign. Well this happenend to me very rarely but I know people who dealt with the frustration of the random disconnects during battles. Dawn of War 2 is connected through its servers all the time, if they suddenly shut down or anything for a split second, youll get kicked out from the campaign to the main menu. (Luckly at most times, the game autosaves).Well thats the best I could, due to the steam limitation I cant write more. I definitely reccomend you buy it. Especially to the Warhammer 40k fans.

content:
Posted: July 29, 2016
												Fans of the Warhammer universe rejoice! Warhammer 40k: Dawn of War II is the sequel to Dawn of War where the epic tale of the Blood Ravens continues.Control & Gameplay:Warhammer 40k: Dawn of War ll renews the Dawn of War genre by adding some new core elements. The well known base building and creation of armies have been replaced by tight squad control, where the micromanagement of these squads will lead to a successful mission. You control each squad's loadout, specialization, abilities and generally everything about them. You will also need to take heed of the terrain, where to take cover, where to move and so on. This might seem as a giant leap away from the first Dawn of War series, and it certainly is. It takes some time to become accustomed with the new game mechanics, but once you get settled, the game is quite enjoyable. In campaign mode, each mission will allow you to choose 4 specialized squads who gain XP and items by completing each mission. There is a fixed number of squads to choose from. In multiplayer, the goal is to capture points and hold them, while building additional squads to supplement your commander in battle. The only building available on the field of battle is the headquarters, from which you can spawn more troops. The controls are accurate and function without any trouble. In multiplayer, however, if a player is experiencing lag issues, it will affect the entire match, thus rendering control of your units more difficult or even impossible, if someone has a high latency. However, this issue is not prevalent, at least not from my experience. Fun Factor:Apart from the new style of gameplay, which can be a huge turn off for some players, Dawn of War ll is as original in its story as the previous games. The story remains rich and plays a significant part in the game, as you uncover dark secrets regarding the unknown past of the Blood Ravens. Currently, the game is being converted to Steamworks from Games for Windows Live. Therefore, if anyone chooses to buy the game now, beware that large segments of multiplayer is currently unavailable for use.Graphics & AudioThe visual aspect of the game is a continuation from the previous style: still dark and gritty, but with added details. The soundtrack is heavy and it enhances the coarse and gritty quality of the game. For the most part, it supplements the game subliminally. After a while, I did not even notice it due to the constant shooting and blowing up of mines, detonation charges and xeno matter flying around. Replayability:I have spent 100+ hours on this game already, so I would argue that the replayability is indeed high. Even more so with the two expansions: Chaos Rising and Retribution. In the original Dawn of War 2, there is a campaign and multiplayer mode. Additionally, the campaign can be played both singleplayer and multiplayer through COOP, which I would highly recommend. Furthermore, another mode was introduced, namely "The Last Stand". Here, a group of 3 commandos are pitted against 20 waves of unrelenting xenos. Definitely worth hours of fun and frustration. Conclusion:Despite the fact that Dawn of War ll has moved away from the original Dawn of War games in terms of mechanics, the game still offers exciting gameplay, a well-structed narrative and solid campaign. Where the older games focused on base building and overwhelming your opponent, the new games focus on managing a handful of specialist squads. Terrain, cover and movement patterns play a larger role in succeeding missions.The game does not run optimally online yet, as the whole net client is being transferred from Games for Windows Live to Steamworks. Therefore, this is the only huge minus about the game, for the time being. This will soon change, and therefore, my rating for this game is positive - 9/10.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
												This game was fantastic. DoW 2 is a squad-based game that plays in real time. Imagine a real-time version of XCOM. With your squads you will defeat hordes of enemies and terrifying bosses. "Purge the alien!". You get to play with Space marines, scouts, force commaders, devastator marines, terminator squadrons, assault marines, and even a dreadnaught! "I have come to destroy you."+A very intersting non-linear storyline. A story you can get invested in, especially towards the ending. Many choices to be made in terms of "Shall I defend this, or shall I let it fall and pursue a more-important objective?"+What I think are amazing graphics, a huge step up for DoW 2, pretty dang good for an RTS in 2009.+The sounds. The sounds of glorious battle. The sounds are great.+A huge variety of weapons and armor to equip you 6 squads with.+Each mission has a "boss" that challenges you once you fight through hordes of their minions, keeping things challenging. Unfortuntaely due to its age its multiplayer is nearly-dead, I could not find a match. Though I could find a match to the arena-based 3 player coop mode.That is fun but not many people are still playing that either. It plays just like the singleplayer game except you control one unit rather than a squad or several squads. Speaking of that, the singleplayer campaign allows for 2 player coop as well, I didn't have a friend to try it with though.I've got to give this game a 9/10, easy. This game trumps almost all others in its genre. It is not perfect, but it is a hell of a lot of fun. I definitely recommend anyone pick it up. $20 seems a bit steep since the multiplayer is dead but if you enjoy singleplayer and coop, maybe you have some friends that will play it with you? Definitely a must-play. "FOR THE EMPEROR!!!"

content:
Posted: March 15, 2014
												Warhammer 40k: Dawn of War II was pretty good. Unlike its predecessor, Dawn of War 1, the base building concept is thrown out the window with this one. Instead it's squad-based, like Company of Heroes for example, which happens to be a Relic game as well. It ends up playing more like an Action RPG really, with you using the specific skills of each of your unique squadmates, each with their own personality and class, collecting new armor, weapons, to change up your playstyle as needed, and last but not least, leveling up and boosting your characters. Hell, even the boss fights keep you on your toes, with their own abilities having you to keep moving around in order to take as little damage as possible. I enjoyed that, and I also enjoyed Relic's streamlined approach to ye olde RTS. And no, streamline does not an easier game make. It very much punished me for getting my priorities wrong when it came to focus fire on the wrong unit. Wasn't a complete cakewalk on Normal difficulty and I'm thankful for that. Though perhaps that could have been because I largely ignored the cover mechanic, which is strongly stressed in these games, yet seldomly did I feel the need to jump into cover.Now Relic knows how to make good RTSes. Not only that, they also know how to give the amazing Warhammer 40k universe the epicness it rightfully deserves. Now I'm not too familiar with the 40k lore at all, but this game got me curious to want to learn more about it, because it just reeks of awesome. The voice acting's awesome, the music fits right into the mood, and the ambience and atmosphere is spot on.The campaign mode isn't Starcraft 2's levels of inventiveness and non linearity, but it's not slouch either. You get all kinds of optional missions to do, special persistent buildings that you can capture that maintain passive bonuses for you throughout the game, that you have to keep defending every now and then against invaders. Though honestly, the missions do get a bit repetitive eventually, and by the end I just wanted to go to the ending and get it over with. Again, it's not because I found this a bad game, I liked it a lot, but I played the Campaign mode only, and RTS single player campaigns are hard to get right. While the old school RTSes didn't care at all about their level design, (build base, kill other guy's base, repeat) Dawn of War II at least gets points in effort for trying to mix it up.As for the story itself, it was admittedly clichéd but again, the epicness of the Warhammer 40k universe is so compelling by itself that I actually want to get Chaos Rising and Retribution eventually just to see how it all unfolds. Dawn of War II was a nice ride, but not one I'd keep coming back to for more over and over again.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
												At first, I thought the sudden change in mechanics from Dawn of War I would steer me clear of this game, especially since the elements of base-building were removed, but after noticing that the Dawn of War II Complete Collection was on sale for a ludicrously low price, I just had to look into it.  While most of the mechanics in Dawn of War II are radically different from its predecessor, it stands on its own for a variety of reasons.  Improved graphics and better sound quality are always welcome, and while the strategic depth of maintaining an army and bases has been replaced with the complexities of managing squads with tactical planning, there are good things to be had from the latter mechanics as well.  The campaign actually gives names and small facets of personalities behind the characters the player uses that would otherwise simply be called "Scout Marine" or "Terminator", along with their own abilities and skill points to boot.  The player is able to determine the loadouts and equipment of their space marine squads, improve their combat prowess through experience, and ultimately understands what it means to be a battle brother.  It's worth noting that the player's actions can actually determine how well they complete the campaign with a score system that also gives the main character a badass title to boast.  The other factions have not been neglected either, the Eldar, Orks, (and in the Chaos Rising DLC The Chaos Marines) are all present with their own skills and strengths their squads provide to mix things up.  While I personally haven't bothered with the multiplayer, it's still fairly active, and speaking of multiplayer unlike Dawn of War I a second player can be invited to help out with one's campaign progress, adding new ways to reach, identify, and overcome different obstacles and objectives.  In Short:  While Dawn of War II may seem quite different from its predecessor, DOWII has its own merits worth noting.  If you prefer managing small numbered groups in a quality-vs-quantity sense and would rather focus on tactics than strategy, this game is for you.

												This game is fun if you are into MOBAs or ARPGs. But if you are looking for a good actuall RTS game or the succesor of the greatest game of all time, this is not one of those. The only positive thing I can say: good graphicsWhat I really really hate about the game:-retreat function-no way to stop the retreat halfway-no view range on strategic points and power noded-no ability to place listening posts on your strat points-victory controll point system-lack of bases-vanilla game was so poorly balanced you kinda had to play the elite mod, banshees could jump over nothing and would die long before they could melee any ranged unit in cover.-open maps (+ poor view range on strat points) allowed enemies always to sneak units behind the lines which would decap all your points before you can react.-original campaign was total boring with just 11 soldiers total instead of 100 soldierspoor pop cap + shared vehicle/infantry cap-can never controll areas because you never have enough units/turrets to cover every acces, and even if you could your army was spread tot thin-small squad sizes-game is more about microing special abilities than it is about troop composition and deploymenttypical game was over before anybody could afford a tier 3 unit.-useless minimap with oversized and ovelapping symbols, made it extremely hard to locate units when they were close to a strat point. The square structure symbol would overlap the power symbol when you build a power nod.summary of gameplay; there is no gameplay really... the only thing you do is micromanaging your squads to capture, decapture and recapture strat points, power nodes and victory points. Capture points faster than the enemy and you will win. From my experience I noticed that you quite litterly spend more time capturing stuff than to attend to actual combat. With so much micromanaging it was not even remotely entertaining to play vs an AI opponent as he would have a unit capping your points 24-7.My oppinion, this game is not even remotely an RTS game for it lacks the S part and as such it is an epic fail as a succesor to dow1. The gameplay is so horribly useless and because of the frustrating micromanaging I could not give 2 damns about the goodgraphics. If it was a standalone game I would give it 4.5/10 as DOW succesor 2.0/10

content:
Posted: June 7, 2015
												Heresy!What do you get when you take a different, albeit risky, spin on a popular franchise? You get Dawn of War II, a squad/tactics-based strategy game set in the Warhammer 40,000 universe which is also the first proper sequel in the Dawn of War series.What is striking in Dawn of War II is how Relic decided to throw away all of the base-building and army management mechanics - staples of the strategy genre - and focus on squad/tactics-based mechanics instead where you can control of up to four (out of six) unique squads and capture points throughout various missions in the campaign. In other words, it is something like taking exclusive control of heroes in Warcraft 3. On top of that, light RPG mechanics were seamlessly implemented to give a bit more depth to the gameplay by allowing the player to level up their squads, assigning attribute points, unlocking new abilities, collecting dropped loot and customizing war-gears to their will; essentially a character progression system. These RPG mechanics, while basic, do provide some diversity in tactics when preparing for a mission. With no prior knowledge of Warhammer 40,000’s lore, aside from these Space Marines worshipping this Emperor of theirs and barbarically killing Tyranids (and other races), as if they are BJ Blazkowicz on steroids, Dawn of War II is actually capable of providing an interesting and somewhat immersive story, albeit nothing new to this genre though, with a fairly strong narrative even to someone who knows absolutely nothing about the Warhammer universe, like myself. About an hour or so in the campaign, you will quickly familiarise yourself with the lore in no time. However, this time around you are allowed to play whichever mission your heart desires in the campaign, with each pick having a certain consequence depending on its objectives. If you want to take a break from the main story-missions, distress calls act as secondary missions for you to complete within a limited time, despite most of them getting generic after a time. At least this creates a layer of non-linearity in the campaign, even if it is all just an illusion. And once again, unquestionable high production values all around coming from someone like Relic, especially in its visuals and voice acting. Where do they find these voice actors?Relic has been known for making good campaigns in their games, even memorable ones as seen in Company of Heroes, but ultimately everyone plays these games for the multiplayer. And there is no denying that Relic did well here too, again. With co-op added, it is possible to play the campaign with a friend and/or battle against each other in either the Victory Point Control or Annihilation modes. But the real meat of the multiplayer is in the Last Stand mode where you have to survive waves of AI controlled units. It is simply addicting and so much fun to play in this mode, especially with a group of friends. No wonder most current servers just run the Last Stand mode, because it is that popular.Sadly where Dawn of War II falls short is in its small and quite uninspiring map designs, repetitiveness in some of its mission objectives and levels, underwhelming boss-fights, squads’ poor path-finding and the lack of other playable races in the campaign (see the expansions packs); having different perspectives from different factions is always a bonus in a story. Also, once you clear out the campaign, there is little reason for coming back to it straightaway since the story, while pretty good, is not worth another playthrough for quite some time; unless you want to play on a higher difficulty, collect all of the achievements or maybe delve into co-op with a friend.And frankly, while the gameplay is probably not as deep (as you may wanted it to be), it can still deliver plenty of hours of fun regardless. Come to think of it, the reason why it is fun is because it is simplified, stripped down from its original roots. No more headaches from micromanaging all your troops across big maps. In actual fact, it is almost like playing a MOBA game, minus some aspects and without that overwhelming depth in gameplay. Moreover, due to the small size of most maps, a mission can take can up to around 15 minutes to complete, with multiplayer matches lasting potentially longer depending on skills. This eliminates the possibility of long-winded plays and getting tired by them, although this is fairly subjective.In conclusion, Dawn of War II is a good example where a developer took the risk to try something dynamically new on a popular and acclaimed franchise to at least satisfactory results. Whether this might have caused them to lose some hardcore fans whilst also gaining new ones, I personally do not care. It is a solid squad/tactics-based strategy game nonetheless, backed up by a story faithful to the Warhammer universe, a well-written narrative, high production values (as we are accustomed from Relic) and a strong multiplayer component thanks to its co-op and Last Stand mode, but definitely not without glaring flaws. Overall nothing mind-blowing, but it is tons of fun. If you are looking for a straightforward traditional RTS, either pick the original Dawn of War or try any other RTS out there instead, if you are desperately missing the good-old base-building and army management mechanics. Otherwise, this is a solid recommendation regardless if you know anything about Warhammer in general.And who needs to wear a helmet in combat when you have oversized body armours which weigh a tonne and have jump packs? Crazy, I know. And very impractical.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												First of all, I am a HUGE fan of Warhammer and Warhammer 40k. I have played first Dawn of War when it was released + DLC Winter Assault and I really liked it a lot. Dawn of War II graphics is way better, gameplay has been changed but I enjoyed this one as well. Missions are now divided into 3 types - story missions, "normal" missions and defend missions. Story and normal missions are basically the same, story missions just drive the story forward. Anyway, it gets repetitive after some time, as its always the same during whole game - deployment of troops into sector, destroying the enemy, capture all strategic points on map and at the end kill some boss - stronger enemy unit. Together with limited number of maps it gets boring sometimes. At least devs included defend missions where cca 3-4 waves of enemies is trying to destroy your acquired strategic point and you need to defend 3 generators. The best way how to enjoy the game is keep some time between playing it or play something else until you have again need to play this. Why? Because its fun! Its fun to watch how your Space Marines troops are crushing your enemies, its fun to listen to their comments, its fun to improve their skills (yes, there are some RPG elements here), to equip them with better weapons/gears etc. Anyway, I would definitely recommend this game. My personal rating - 8/10

content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												The Dawn of War 2 (and Chaos Rising as it is really an extension of Dow2) campaign is great fun to play through with a friend in co-op. The missions are challenging, the atmosphere is great and the cutscenes really add to the atmosphere (and I am not a fan of cutscenes). Highly recommended. Plus Relic are definitely good guys when it comes to long term support. Full marks to Relic for patching out the awful Games for Windows Live and replacing it with Steamworks. They did not have to, but chose to and for that I think they are very cool and it makes me far more likely to buy future games (Dawn of War 3 please!)Dawn of War 2 is a really great adaptation of the 40k universe - it strips out the base building of Dawn of War 1 and focusses on small units and heroes, which is much closer to the fiction and the miniatures game. Some people did not like that, but I definitely did. You control up to 4 squads (or 2 squads each if you are playing co-op) and fight a variety of foes each of which benefit from different strategies of attack. There is also a larger meta-game element of controlling various resource sites and that works pretty well too.All in all I highly rate Dawn of War 2 and Chaos Rising.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												I've been playing the Warhammer 40k tabletop game since 2002 (originally with Space Wolves, now rolling with Word Bearers and Astra Militarum) and I loved the original Dawn of War. Dawn of War II has more in common with Relic's Company of Heroes series then it does the original Dawn of War, in single-player games anyways, as you are only in command of small groups of Space Marines. No massive armies of vehicles, fliers and Squiggoths in this one. Despite the reduced scale, Dawn of War II is still one of the best squad-based RTS games available. The graphics still look good, the music is the typical "epic" soundtrack and matches the grim dark setting. Control is perhaps the largest issue as it can be hard to get your squads to go into cover and it gets tough to pick out enemy characters.  Keyboard hotkeys help but it's still annoying. All told, for the price, Dawn of War II is a great pick up if you want a small scale RTS or just a decent game in the 40k Universe.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2016
												This game is very repetitive and formulaic. Every mission is basically just land, kill some orcs, reactivate some things, go find a generic looking orc boss (with generic voice acting and generic video game boss type abilities) and kill him. I played 5 missions, but felt as if I had played only 1 mission because they were all the same. The missions are connected by what I would very hesitantly call a primitive "storyline". It basically consists of some voice-acted space marine saying some generic stuff like "ok well there's this big ork guy and he's causing problems, go kill him". Every mission briefing is pretty much exactly that phrase re-worded to give the illusion of unique missions. The mission content itself doesn't differ much either. Maybe instead of fighting shoota boys, you're fighting stromboys. Or instead of killing an orc warboss in a canyon, you're killing an orc warboss on a mountain top. Or instead of killing ork warboss A who did this one bad thing, you're killing ork warboss B who did another bad thing. See where I'm going with this? You would think that RTS games would have learned from the game design which Blizzard pioneered which included vibrant characters and storylines.The actual mechanics of the gameplay as lacking as well. One thing that makes squad combat games awesome as opposed to army combat/basebuilding games is that you can focus on more meaningful and deep strategic elements relating to the combat engagements themselves. Ostensibly, with less things to control, the micromanagement of what you do control can be more complex. Not so with this game. What you're able to do with a few squads is pretty much the same thing you do with mass engagements. You activate one or two powers or utlility items for max efficiency and that's pretty much it. In other words, all the boring stuff. It's clicky micromanagement and not STRATEGICAL micromanagement. Think the hero missions in starcraft and warcraft, only slowed down. Now true, you can take cover. However, most of the time it isn't necessary and doesn't exactly constitute high tactics. It just means that the game is clicky: click for cover, click to shoot, click to activate ability, click to pick up items, rinse and repeat. The only curve ball that forces you to adapt is when enemies throw grenades or a boss marks a circle of ground that he will soon jump on. But all you have to do is micro your squad away from it and move them back. Again, it's the tedious and boring kind of micro (and not that hard either), as opposed to the strategical kind of micro. This game doesn't encourage careful thinking, risk vs. reward, and lot of out-of-the-box thinking. Some tactics that I came up with were immediately shut down by the game. For example, you can't lure enemies into a killzone because they have a leash. Hit and run or guerilla type tactics don't work for the same reason. Scout units are largely worthless because you can see enemies farther away than they can see you. Basically, the player is forced to play the game one way. You don't even need to think about how best to use limited use items either because the game constantly re-supplies you.Moving on to the other areas. This game has a very rudimentary character progression system. You can assign some stat points. There are only 4 stats though, and they all progress in a linear fashion with little player input. To go along with this system is a gear collection system. It's very incremental and done with the classic white/green/blue scale. Some weapons and armors are objectively better than others, removing any sense of tactical considerations. The right way to do this would to have lots of gear, none of which is better or worse, but just has different tactical implications. Sadly, none of the gear changes the way you approach battles too much, opting to give you better armor or damage or health instead.      As far as production value, I would say the graphics are fine but the voice acting sucks. The layout of the hud and menus is rather poor as well. Overall this game is below average standards for RTS games. I bought it for 5 bucks on a sale and wish I could get my money back.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2015
												Dawn of War II is a very divisive game, it's really nothing like its prequel.  Somewhere between the two games, Relic released another stellar RTS (Company of Heroes) that fundamentally changed the way RTS games play; it was a game less focused on base building and throwing huge armies at each other, but more focused on advancing technology and tactical engagements.  Dawn of War II takes over from there, and iterates the formula into the 40K setting.  Gone are the micromanaged bases and huge armies of Dawn of War fighting Epic-like battles.  You will lead smaller and fewer squads and named heroes, with ability progression and customizable wargear, choose your battles on a campaign map, receive rewards/loot, customize your hero and ultimately stick it to the filthy Xenos.  Don't jump in expecting Starcraft/C&C type of RTS gameplay, keep an open mind, and you will be rewarded with an incredibly rewarding campaign experience leading the Blood Ravens and their familiar heroes to victory and salvation.  Dawn of War II has graphics that still measure up to this day, and its requirements should be a piece of cake for any modern system.  Its campaign coop is incredibly fun, so I strongly suggest that you nag a friend into buying it with you.  Final caveat: Do not buy it for its multiplayer; for that, buy the standalone expansion Dawn of War II: Retribution.

content:
Posted: April 5
												DoW II is a huge departure from the original games, but not necessarily in a bad way. You most likely know that this game is a real time tactics game, rather than a real time strategy title. The difference being you control a few squads of Marines, with heavy amounts of micro needed to perform well. I generally hate that style of gameplay, but the plot and progression system are so engaging that it made up for that change in gameplay for me. Being able to outfit my men before each mission and decide their specializations was a blast, and really made me feel as if they were my troops. If you are a 40k fan you will undoubtedly enjoy this game because it is not only an objectively solid game, but it is 40k to the core. The grimdark aesthetics and brutality are still enjoyable to this day, and the satisfaction of slaughtering your enemies has not grown faint after all these years

content:
Posted: October 30, 2016
												Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War II is a real-time strategy / tactical role-playing video game developed by Relic Entertainment and published by THQ for Microsoft Windows based on the fictional Warhammer 40,000 universe. It is the sequel to the Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War video game series.  Dawn of War II features a non-linear interplanetary campaign, as the Space Marines. The campaign can be played either as single-player or cooperatively with another player through an online connection.The game's campaign departs from those of its predecessors in several key features. One of the most notable departures is that there are no base-building elements, unlike in previous Dawn of War titles. Instead, the player chooses the units to be used prior to beginning a mission, cannot build new units once the mission begins, and has only limited reinforcement options. Has several multiplayer modes of play.for more info:

content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
												This is Dawn of War II, while I do recommend this game, bare in mind it is NOT like its predecessor, I would call Dawn of  War a classical RTS with a base-capture element, while this is more of a action-oriented tactical RPG with more units. The Campaign is the best mode in my opinion or the online area modes and you won't be constructing buildings at all, all you will do in the regular 1 vs 1 mode is producing units. Controlling units, bases and manage economy but there are no build orders you just upgrade your current base to build more units.A lot of people, myself included did not like this change. I am a big fan of 4X, strategy and RTS games, but this is more of a RPG, I would say the campaign itself is totally worth it if you buy it on a sale, then go ahead, and get ready to gear up your own space marine squad.And the customization in the campaign is awesome, you want to give Terminator Armour to Assault Marines? They pick up the Thunder Hammers, give it to your marines and they turn into regular old Terminators, want some extra range for your assault gun-carrying Termies? Then give 'em the good cyclone missle launcher and let loose havoc.The campaign really is the peak of this game and it lets you play from many different angles, but do keep in mind from an RTS point of view, Dawn of War I is the better multiplayer online game. But DoW also lets you play co-op in the campaign so if you just want to enjoy the Epic Space Marine bad assery with friends then totally pick this game up.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2015
												Dawn of War 2 forgoes its mix of micro and macro management gameplay from its previous series and focuses it all on small squad micro management. Here the player relies now more than ever on using terrain for squad, and structures as vantage points. This creates the pacing for multiplayer matches to become more about capture points rather than destruction of your enemy base. They have also removed creating tech tree structures, and streamlined the tech tree onto a single building.You still have your unit upgrades per squad, and your race specific Heroes. But the cost for upgrades have increased, thus putting more weight onto fewer decisions. Replenishing squad units aren’t on the fly anymore, healing is only available at base. And, since there’s no mention of constructing a new base, you have only one location to heal, your starting point.A match last about 30 minutes. However, the balancing feels a bit tilted. On a classic destruction game mode, if you control all the resources on the field within 10 minutes, you’ll find yourself spending the other 20 minutes trying to just break their base... unless if the AI happened to obtain unlimited resources, it appears they can heal almost indefinitely without any resource nodes. This is why they’ve probably added and defaulted the game mode to Capture Points, where you win by controlling the nodes.If you want to compare this to other game genres, this would be similar to playing a DoTA/MoBA but with a single player controlling all the units on the field. While enjoyable to play, Dawn of War 2 is not my cup of tea.

content:
Posted: March 27, 2015
												I am just going to take a minute and write down a few thoughts I have had about this game as well as the additional games in this entire franchise. Because it is on a sale at this particular time I am jotting this down, I see from time to time a lot of people who wonder if they should get this game. The quick and easy answer is of course a most definite YES!, and I think for two very good reasons.I will go ahead and put as the #1 reason is that, given how long this game has been out, the developers Relic Entertainment is in my opinion one the best video game development studios to have ever come along. They have done such an incredible job with the way they made this game. Everything from the production values to the voice over acting is just a perfect example of putting big budget resources to good use. Another thing about this is, if you take a moment to look at the news and announcements pages for these games, Relic  is supporting this series and franchise to its fullest extent. There are lots of updates and general postings being made about these games on a constant basis to this day. Good communication with your player base goes a loooong way to helping people make good decisions about what games they should buy.The #2 reason I could recommend getting this series and games, is that the level of polish and overall feel of the games themselves is very top notch. These games run extremely well across a huge variety of PC configurations, low end systems to the very latest PC's. Along with this is that these games play very good without huge game-breaking bugs ruining your playing experience, seems like Relic did a great job with making sure as many bugs were taken care of before they released this series a long time ago, in general I found that all of Relic's older games including CoH, The Homeworld series, etc. were done very well.Some of the other things I enjoy about this series is that while I don't know a whole lot about the Warhammer Universe, I thought the story and characters are good enough to be interesting. Great campaign play, Good multiplayer action, and just altogether a solid, nicely done game series.And lastly, I should go ahead and mention specifically that the DoW II games are just slightly different from the original W40K DoW series. The original DoW series had a classic C&C base-building, resource gathering model while the DoW II series switches over and gets rid that in favor of a squad based, heroes model.Some people were surprised at the change, some liked it while others didn't, in my opinion it looked as if they wanted to go the other direction and that was fine. I would recommend in fact that anybody who wonders what the big difference is, is to maybe watch a youtube game review/let's play video that way you could see for yourself and decide that way because no one but you can decide if you would like that or not.

content:
Posted: February 15
												Kinda fun but mostly frustrating gameplay that leaves you wishing GW would just make a full digital version of their tabletop wargame. Your squads take cover, fire, and have some special abilities that the enemy instinctually moves out of the way of (those eldar farseers have seen the future, they knew you would throw a grenade there). The battles can be fun but become monotonous after a mission or two. The boss fights are slug-fests against a massive hitpoint enemy that typically runs over or smashes your guys killing them instantly in one hit. The tactics to the boss fights center around you comically keeping one guy alive and trying to revive your men after they are one-shotted over and over. The game makes you wonder wtf is going on when your supposed elite super warrior melee badass captain is one shotted by what is considered a routine troop in the tabletop game. You will end up wishing the game was more dynamic and allowed you to format your attacks and strategies like an actual Adeptus Astartes commander, but honestly you just feel like an IG commander throwing mindless expendable guardsmen against the xeno tide.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
												Dawn of War II is perhaps the best example of a sequel outside of StarCraft II in the RTS genre. While it tossed out Base Building for a more streamlined approach, it did so with flying colors combining Diablo style loot drops with an RPG leveling system and an extensive skill tree.Pros: +Decent story with likeable characters+Excellent loot, weapon, armor, and class variety+Great graphics and animations that still hold up to todays standards for RTS games, especially for 2009+TONS OF CONTENT! On top of a 20+ hour campaign that is highly replayable, you have Co-Op on top of that. (The online modes should be played exclusively on DoW II Retribution though as that has ALL the factions and the majority of the community.)+Fantastic combat with great enemy variety, boss battles, special enemy types, and lots of guns, powers, and toys to play around with+Huge open maps meant for exploration to find loot and other goodies as well as mop up any enemies to rack the experience points.+Decent mission variety with story missions being the most focused with optional Assassination and Defense missions to spice it up+The voice acting is SUPERB with some of the best game actors in the biz working it, including Steve Blum, aka Spike from Cowboy Beebop in this game as a grizzled Sniper expert+ITS WARHAMMER 40K! If you love the franchise like I do you will be splooging at all the detail, lore, and awesome stuff that helps build upon the license and makes you giddy just to feel like youre in the universe of W40KCon: -Graphics are great overall, but there is some serious texture quality that is left to be desired, like the ground for instance-While the maps are expansive and fun to explore they repeat them CONSTANTLY in the game. It gets repeitive doing the same maps over and over, but it's the quality of the gameplay and the map design that save this unfortunate problem-Cant respec skill tree :(-Still suffers from bugs. Nothing major, but there are occasional animation bugs where units may get stuck or cant move, and enemies who get killed may fly in circles around the map. It's actually kind of funny when you see that one though-Along with repeating maps the missions themselves feel very repetitive after a while. It's the differing enemy types and awesome loot drops that encourage you to play these and save this unforunate repetition-While the writing is passable by W40K fans, most people will see it as stock and cliche. It really is the setting and license that hold it up. The characters are memorable and likeable enough, but fairly one dimensional in personality and you really need to listen to a LOT of their dialog to feel investedOVERALL: FantasticI mean no exageration when I award this a 9.5/10 as a W40K fan. As an RTS/RPG fan, I award it an 8.5 for those not familiar with W40K. An excellent game none the less and one of my favorite games of all time and my favorite RTS alongside StarCraft II. An easy buy.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 20, 2016
A Unique Blend of RTS and RPGPros:A great Warhammer 40K experience. You can tell the developer cared for and respected the Warhammer IP. They did a great job of delving into the 40K lore and made it accessible for everyone.It's a great co-op experience. Playing through the campaign with a friend was extremely enjoyable.Even though it is now starting to get dated, the game still looked great. Lots of graphical options.Plenty of variance in enemy units and environments. It takes a while before it starts to feel repetitive.Aside from the campaign there is also PVP and AI Multiplayer, and a wave survival co-op mode called The Last Stand.Neutral:I'm ashamed to admit that I haven't played the original Dawn of War. That being said I really enjoyed having the small squads with heroes. Managing hero abilities and moving squads kept me quite busy, and the lack of micromanaging was a breath of fresh air. That being said I'm sure it's not everyone's cup of tea.Cons:The online multiplayer community is slowly shrinking, as would be expected as a game gets older. Finding well matched games is only going to get harder and harder.21:9 displays are supported, however, Some of the UI and loading screen are bugged or don't display correctly. Obviously won't effect most people, but it's kind of a big deal to people with ultrawides.

Posted: March 27, 2015
												I am just going to take a minute and write down a few thoughts I have had about this game as well as the additional games in this entire franchise. Because it is on a sale at this particular time I am jotting this down, I see from time to time a lot of people who wonder if they should get this game. The quick and easy answer is of course a most definite YES!, and I think for two very good reasons.I will go ahead and put as the #1 reason is that, given how long this game has been out, the developers Relic Entertainment is in my opinion one the best video game development studios to have ever come along. They have done such an incredible job with the way they made this game. Everything from the production values to the voice over acting is just a perfect example of putting big budget resources to good use. Another thing about this is, if you take a moment to look at the news and announcements pages for these games, Relic  is supporting this series and franchise to its fullest extent. There are lots of updates and general postings being made about these games on a constant basis to this day. Good communication with your player base goes a loooong way to helping people make good decisions about what games they should buy.The #2 reason I could recommend getting this series and games, is that the level of polish and overall feel of the games themselves is very top notch. These games run extremely well across a huge variety of PC configurations, low end systems to the very latest PC's. Along with this is that these games play very good without huge game-breaking bugs ruining your playing experience, seems like Relic did a great job with making sure as many bugs were taken care of before they released this series a long time ago, in general I found that all of Relic's older games including CoH, The Homeworld series, etc. were done very well.Some of the other things I enjoy about this series is that while I don't know a whole lot about the Warhammer Universe, I thought the story and characters are good enough to be interesting. Great campaign play, Good multiplayer action, and just altogether a solid, nicely done game series.And lastly, I should go ahead and mention specifically that the DoW II games are just slightly different from the original W40K DoW series. The original DoW series had a classic C&C base-building, resource gathering model while the DoW II series switches over and gets rid that in favor of a squad based, heroes model.Some people were surprised at the change, some liked it while others didn't, in my opinion it looked as if they wanted to go the other direction and that was fine. I would recommend in fact that anybody who wonders what the big difference is, is to maybe watch a youtube game review/let's play video that way you could see for yourself and decide that way because no one but you can decide if you would like that or not.
