												Having been completely obsessed with the first DoW game for years and putting in countless hours into online ranked and frantic base building and huge battles, DoW 2 came as a massive suprise to me. Although I prefer the first game, I can appreciate the change in direction and am enjoying the campaign so far. I do feel this game is a little tedious at times (I find myself dipping into it for an hour and coming back another time) but maybe this is because, I feel, this is a game that is much more catered to a more casual approach rather than 50 minute, off the scale RTS stratergy battles. Overall, seeing as I'd give DoW a 10/10, I feel DoW 2 deserves a 6.5. It's quite fun and the customising of your commanders is cool, but I feel like once I've completed the campaign they'll be little in the way to keep me coming back for more.Here's to DoW3 and the return of base building. Hurrah!

content:
Posted: July 31, 2014
												Hey you! Yes you! Would you like to command a squad in an epic battle against countless enemies across a subsector? Well in Warhammer 40,000 Dawn of War 2 you can do just that! in this game you play as a force commander of the Blood Ravens Space Marines and you lead a small team of elite soldiers in defence of the Blood Ravens recruiting worlds (aka homeworlds) in the Aurealia sub-system. Now gameplay wise, this game is a great example of squad based tactics done in a reasonable fashion due to the hordes of enemies you have to face down with just a hand full of men. The only problem i have with the gameplay is that it does away with the base building of the previous Dawn of War but if you look at this game as if it were a plot sequal and not a gameplay sequal then the game is actually rather good.I fully reccomend this game to anyone who likes a nice good fast-paced RTS that requires you to think on your feet and look at everything with a tactical eye.

												More of an RPG than an RTS and with crap multiplayer as a result, I'd advise anyone to avoid this unless all they want out of it is a decent campaign. Even then you'll encounter plenty of bugs that can screw you over, like a squad being too stupid to stop attempting to use an item or ability they can't seem to ♥♥♥♥ing figure out how to do which will glue them to the ground and leave you with only 3 squads to complete a mission you'll likely then have to restart. Mele squads will sit there twiddling their thumbs in the middle of battle and ranged squads will follow the enemy and get caught in mele, because ♥♥♥♥ proper unit logic.It looks good enough for its time if not pretty good. content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												For once, a good Warhammer 40k game! Where should I start? This game focuses on its singleplayer campaign rather than the (rather unattended) multiplayer, but I'm okay with that. The characters are well written (I'm pretty sure we're supposed to hate Avitus, but I hate Cyrus), the story is brilliant, and the gameplay is immensely entertaining. Everything you do has a "feel" to it, as if it matters. Every mission felt like you actually accomplished something; every boss killed giving you a sense of triumph and honour.The final mission was lackluster, however. The final boss in said mission was easier to kill than the first boss. In fact, the whole ending portion was extremely rushed, expecting you to waste time repeating the exact same "defend the array" missions for hours before executing the final mission. Besides that, I would give this game a solid 8.5/10. I would certainly recommend this.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2015
												For those expecting a sequel to Dawn of War be prepared to be slightly disappointed because the threads of similarity are very thin. Yes it’s based in the 40K universe, Space Marines battling Orks etc. But that is it, Dawn of War 2 is a game in its own right, you will not be amassing squads of soldiers capturing strategic locations to earn more points so you can build more units faster. In fact the main emphasis will be around a small group of rock hard units which you will take (or not) on missions amass experience and hopefully pick up wargear. Dawn of War was a RTS pure and simple, Dawn of War 2 is a cross between RTS and RPG. I enjoyed playing the game in its own right and would highly recommend it for both RTS, RPG and 40K fans.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2015
												This game is a fantastic RTS where you can play the fantastic single player or multiplayer. In the singleplayer you take control of the Blood Ravens chapter of space marines as battle your way across three different planets attempting to stop any threat to humanity. In the multiplayer you can play as any of four races (Space Marines, Orks, Eldar, and Tyranids) and attempt to get more victory points than your opponent or to destroy their base. Along with these modes there is also the Last Stand mode where you and two other players can each take control one of 3-5 (Depends on if you have Chaos Rising and Retribution) different "heroes" and fight off waves of AI controlled units. In general, if you like RTS games you should buy this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2016
												A really good, yet simple RTS. The campaign is really neat, dynamic, and engaging. The minute you feel the game becomes repetitive a new element is added, and as soon as you feel that your game is playing too long, it comes to one of these, or draws out to an end. A great way to throw an RTS together in an RPG fashion, and multiplayer is great and was saved from the horrendous experience that was dealing with GFWL. The singleplayer campaign can be played as a co-op, and there are survival and PvP multiplayer modes. Anyone whos a fan or newcomer of the Warhammer 40,000 Universe should love this game, as it was also well executed with wonderful graphics and audio. The soundtrack is great, but as all do, it eventually gets old. Without bugging people, both campaigns reteach you how to play, making this a great start or start-and-stop for new RTS players. The base game can out plenty of hours, infact just getting the first campaign playthrough alone can easily take over 12 hours, and the DLCs are a great extension to the story of the game!

content:
Posted: November 20, 2014
												For none-tabletop players: 9 of 10 stars.For all those of you, who love playing the mix of strategy games and RPG's, its an awesome game.You can choose a race like Space Marines (gen-manipulated super soldiers in the heaviest armors you can imagine), orkz (big, green and tons of aggression), the imperial Army ( normal humans, throw-away-units, but like a mass army, they overrun every enemy) and many others.While playing, your units gain experience and level up. So you can raise their stats and change the equipment of every hero in your squad.The game is split up in more or less 15 missions, individualized for each of the races.Otherwise you can play the ,,last stand", where you and 2 other players try to survive 20 waves of enemys.Last aspect of the game is the multiplayer mode, where you can play solo or in team against other players.For tabletop players: 7 of 10 stars.Of course the game is still epic. But there are a few bad mistakes in the game, which let your smile disappear....Much of the equipment isn't codexconform, there are characters and Chapters that doesn't exist, an exterminatus that isn't an exterminatus ((it's an overkill in game.....first thousands of lances, and then a magmabomb which is much bigger than usual)(and although it's an planet with a great flora and fauna, there are no virusbombs)).Ok, this could be called pedantically, but if you know the codex and the rulebook, you will notice theese things wether you like or not...In spite of everything i advise you to buy this game ;)

												For none-tabletop players: 9 of 10 stars.For all those of you, who love playing the mix of strategy games and RPG's, its an awesome game.You can choose a race like Space Marines (gen-manipulated super soldiers in the heaviest armors you can imagine), orkz (big, green and tons of aggression), the imperial Army ( normal humans, throw-away-units, but like a mass army, they overrun every enemy) and many others.While playing, your units gain experience and level up. So you can raise their stats and change the equipment of every hero in your squad.The game is split up in more or less 15 missions, individualized for each of the races.Otherwise you can play the ,,last stand", where you and 2 other players try to survive 20 waves of enemys.Last aspect of the game is the multiplayer mode, where you can play solo or in team against other players.For tabletop players: 7 of 10 stars.Of course the game is still epic. But there are a few bad mistakes in the game, which let your smile disappear....Much of the equipment isn't codexconform, there are characters and Chapters that doesn't exist, an exterminatus that isn't an exterminatus ((it's an overkill in game.....first thousands of lances, and then a magmabomb which is much bigger than usual)(and although it's an planet with a great flora and fauna, there are no virusbombs)).Ok, this could be called pedantically, but if you know the codex and the rulebook, you will notice theese things wether you like or not...In spite of everything i advise you to buy this game ;)

content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
												LONG REVIEW, WITH TL,DR AT THE END.I did not play the previous Warhammer 40k RTS games before Dawn of War II, yet I'm aware how different they are and I understand why some may not like Dawn of War II as the next evolution of the Dawn of War series. It's true, it is completely different, through that's no reason for hate or prejudgement. Dawn of War II on it's own is a fantastic game, I risk to say maybe ageless to be picked up again years after for it's campign, and if you don't expect an FPS game to be TPS, you'll realize if everything else other than the perspective is marvelously done, you have a great game.The same applies to Dawn of War II. It has left behind base building completely, the entire campign is leading a relatively small elite force, in a gameplay setting that is equal to classic RTS games, plus you have the cover system from Company of Heroes, and a lot RPG elements. This, as is, works freaking great. You expect it be a base building resource gathering army building game, well it's not, and that's no reason to hate it (reacting to the negative reviews).The gameplay itself is fluid, smart. Tactics, strategies, adapting to new situations and changing (destroyable) enviromentis vital to success, and can be greatly different from playthrough to playthrough, from player to player, depending on the playstyle, RPG build (skill tree and equipment that drasticly change your squad) you choose.The graphics are fantastic up to this day, even if the game can be considered "somewhat aged" in 2016, if someone would ask me to pick a classic RTS (classic as in not 10000000000 units at once Total War, more like Command and Conquer used to be)  with the best looks, I'd pick Dawn of War 2 today, even over Company of Heroes 2 that came after it from the same company. The music is great and totally hooks you in, the voice distorsions, the deep bass when an assault rifle with bullets sized like my leg fire, the often seemingly endless swarm of orks and tyranids really support the feeling of a brutal war where 3m tall living warmachine of men punch space orks and locusts in the face with an armored fist that hits like a train. The FEELING is really there, despite the low number of units under our control that are mostly observed from a bird's perspective, and that is proof of professional work. Add that to the excellent gameplay, and you have a great game. The campign is lengthy, and generates endless sidemissions for global terrirorial control additionally to the main missions. The story is really nothing to be bothered with, it does it's job, it's there, but it is the gameplay you'll want to have Dawn of War II for.Multiplayer. Well... this is much like the singleplayer (for which you should buy this game), and not at all. Hardly traditional, just like the singleplayer - if you usually avoid RTS multiplayer because you get crushed by people with high APM (action-per-minute, how fast they play), Dawn of War II is for you. You don't have to worry about managing home, high APM, it's all about tactics, but also territorial control with the capture points giving resources and different capture points you must hold to win. This mechanism isn't present in singleplayer at all, and you build normal units instead of heroes with a squad. Microing your units may be even more important than in StarCraft 2, but without the pressure of multitasking knowing that if you micro a lot and let your base idle, you lost the next fight. Non of that. Be a good strategist, you'll be good here - though, multiplayer is dead in this version, grab the Retribution standalone expansion for this! Check out my review on the Last Stand, which is a coop hero based survival multiplayer mode, but could be (and even is sold as now) a separate game, but it is included here aswell if you are curious.TL,DRWHAT TO BUY DAWN OF WAR 2 FOR?If you want a lenghty campign and you are not bothered by it being repetitive, but rather see the opportunity to battle harden yourself and your heroic squads with various tactics in a great RTS enviroment, supported with RPG elements that change your squad from mission to mission on your choice, to try new compositions. Much like Devil May Cry games, you  replay it for being better at fights, and not look at them as "another same target". It's exciting, challanging, and evolving on the fly.WHAT NOT TO BUY DAWN OF WAR 2 FOR?If you are looking for the classic RTS gameplay with base building, army building, resource harvesting. These days the best choice you have for that is StarCraft II, and maybe Grey Goo though I have not played the latter yet. If you like it as is, but primary reason of purchase would be multiplayer, buy W40K:DOW2: Retribution instead. While the campign is definitly subpar compared to Dawn of War II + Chaos Rising, the multiplayer is entirely living there.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2016
												A really good, yet simple RTS. The campaign is really neat, dynamic, and engaging. The minute you feel the game becomes repetitive a new element is added, and as soon as you feel that your game is playing too long, it comes to one of these, or draws out to an end. A great way to throw an RTS together in an RPG fashion, and multiplayer is great and was saved from the horrendous experience that was dealing with GFWL. The singleplayer campaign can be played as a co-op, and there are survival and PvP multiplayer modes. Anyone whos a fan or newcomer of the Warhammer 40,000 Universe should love this game, as it was also well executed with wonderful graphics and audio. The soundtrack is great, but as all do, it eventually gets old. Without bugging people, both campaigns reteach you how to play, making this a great start or start-and-stop for new RTS players. The base game can out plenty of hours, infact just getting the first campaign playthrough alone can easily take over 12 hours, and the DLCs are a great extension to the story of the game!

content:
Posted: February 28, 2015
												After having a blast with the original Dawn of War (review link) I decided to pick up the sequel, and I'm glad that I did.The Blood Ravens are back to dispense Space Marine justice once again, and this time it's personal!I don't mean that they have actual personal investments in the story or anything though, this is Warhammer after all.The main difference this time around is that you only control a small number of hero squads (usually 4) in each level, so the focus is far more on squad management and tactics than the previous game. The previous game had some of that too, but definitely a lot of economy and base building too. None of that here though, this is purely a combat game.Your heroes level up as they purge the xenos (that's Space Marine for killing just about everything) and each level up grants them a passive stat boost, 2 skill points and access to better gear (which drops randomly from enemies you kill, almost like an ARPG, but fortunately not quite as frequently).These skill points (and your choice of weapon type and accessories) are your primary means of customization, and you can spend them on 4 attributes. Health, Ranged, Melee and Energy. The first 3 are self-explanatory, and Energy just gives you more "mana" to use your abilities in battle. What elevates this system to something far more strategic though, is that specific levels in an attribute can give very specific effects. For example, putting 3 points in Energy could unlock an additional accessory slot or allow your units to equip plasma rifles.There aren't enough skill points to get everything though, as the maximum level is 20 (for your units anyway, I've seen enemy AI with level 27 units... I hate it when games do that). This means that you'll have to decide how to develop your units quite early on, and with no way to respec them and a total of 6 (steady) party members unlocked as the game progresses it is possible that you screw up your build and will have a harder time.In general the game is pretty fair though, and as long as you don't split up your squad or rush into enemy fire unprepared (which will 'suppress' your squad, drastically lowering its movement speed) you should be okay. There is a range of difficulty settings too, though this can't be changed once you start your campaign.I personally went through the game on the lowest difficulty setting, Recruit, and felt sufficiently challenged (lost 2 optional missions, which I was then able to redo at a later time).The story is the standard 40k fare. Sub-sector Aurelia is important to every 40k race, and as the Imperium presence is overrun with Orks the Blood Ravens are called in. This quickly escalates into a conflict against the insidious Eldar and relentless Tyranid as well.In general I had a great time with this game, and I'd definitely recommend it.You're still only able to play as the Space Marines, and they're still stupidly serious about everything, but as a power fantasy they definitely deliver.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
"None can stop the crusade of the righteous."-Captain Davian Thule, Blood Ravens Commander, Sub-sector AureliaI recently replayed Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War II from Relic Entertainment & THQ/SEGA.  I can gladly report that it still has the magic it did back in 2009.  Remarkably to this day it remains the most quintessential Warhammer experience to be found in videogaming, arguably tied with the action title, Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine.  I doubt DoW2 will be knocked from that top spot by either Warhammer: End Times - Vermintide or the upcoming Total War entry to the IP.  Not sure whether or not to get my hopes up for Eternal Crusade.Note: This review is strictly for the original game; I've played the expansions but don't own them on Steam, and I'll make no comment on those expansions at the time of this writing except to say they're excellent; Chaos Rising adds diversity and great content.  I also did not engage the alternate game modes or multiplayer, only the single player campaign, so I make no comment on those here either.Of the four difficulty settings (Recruit, Sergeant, Captain & Primarch) I did a full playthrough on normal (Sergeant).  At this level, you can pretty much roll through the entire game without worrying overmuch about careful use of abilities or cover.  Not ideal for the RTS veteran but preferable to quickly absorb the campaign story.In this mission based campaign you're allowed one or more deployments per day.  Each mission is rated based on your performance in three categories (offense, survival & speed).  Ratings are also affected by certain side objectives.  Overall rating is presented to the player on campaign completion.Core gameplay is in squad dynamics.  There are: Force Commander, Tactical Marine, Devastator Marine, Assault Marine, Scout & Dreadnought.  I found the gameplay to have a balance of accessibility & depth.  Choosing the right squad composition & gear is half the battle in any mission; the other half requires timely use of cover & abilities.There's plenty of RPG progression mixed in, including gear, experience, attributes, traits and skills.  Gear is looted in mission or given as a reward; each squad can equip weapons, armor, accessories & consumables that should be tailored to the needs of each mission.  You'll gain 2 points per level to put into attributes (Stamina, Ranged, Melee, Energy) & earn strategy altering traits.Your 1st mission on any given day shouldn't be a Defense - those are more difficult to acquire high ratings in for some reason.  It's your performance in that 1st mission that determines how many extra deployments (none, one or two) you receive.  As such, make the 1st one strong to nab extra deployments.On that note, prioritize capturing Foundries over Comm Arrays or Imperial Shrines when possible, since of those three resources it's the Foundry that gives bonus to mission rating for the purpose of earning extra deployment.  Your ability to complete one or two extra missions per day is critical to keeping ahead of the enemy, especially late campaign.  As for the other two resources, I found the shrine bonus (a limited use per mission invulnerability shield) to be slightly more useful than the Comm Array (a targeted orbital strike, also limited use per mission).While Force Commander items like the drop pod beacon & other big area of effect attacks are fun & have a lot of flair, they should be used cautiously; they can & will hit squads too close to the target zone, potentially killing them outright (hurting your Survival score for that mission).Squads that frequently sit on the sideline can & will fall behind your regular squads in level a bit, even with the "Librarium" feature which lets the player discard spare items in exchange for experience.  Being lower in level, they'll also inevitably be comparatively undergeared, so rotate them a bit.My biggest issue with the game is no option for restarting a mission, no quicksave or quickload, no manual saving at all except between missions.  Once you load into that mission, you must complete it for better or worse; if you close the game, a day will have passed in your campaign automatically.  It's a bother if you mess up badly, since you have to live with the poor mission rating afterwards.  Of course plenty of players and developers embrace this tough stance towards saving/loading, as it raises the stakes!  Thankfully maps aren't so big as to draw out mission length too much.Story is very straightforward Warhammer fare, with a fun cast of squad leaders to walk you through it.  Visuals, audio & production value leave little to be said, although it does look a bit better than the average game from the year 2009.  There were no technical issues or bugs that I encountered.It's frustrating that the continuation of the Dawn of War series has been complicated by changing ownership & THQ's fate.  I'll believe there's a third installment in the works only when I can click the preorder button on Steam's store page!  WH40K:DoW2 is showing its age visually but is otherwise an admirably well crafted game that holds up to modern standards well enough; I highly recommend it for the excellent science fiction and solid RTS strategy - and obviously it's a must play for any Warhammer fan.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2015
												The game that first took me down the rabbit hole that is WARHAMMER 40000, this is one terrific experience. Quick version: if you like WARHAMMER 40k, buy it. If you like RTS games, buy it. Long version: Dawn of War II is a tight-playing squad-based RTS that feels just right for my brain. The campaign is a ton of fun, with lots of loot to collect and abilities to unlock. You’ll want to tackle multiple playthroughs to try out different character builds. Deliciously campy and fun voice acting abounds. The multiplayer is terrific as well, plus the recent removal of the much hated Games For Windows Live makes it all the sweeter.Get the whole franchise package when it goes on cheap. You’ll get a solid 30 hours at least out of DOW II and its two excellent expansions and never look back.PURGE THE XENOS

content:
Posted: July 22, 2015
												I intially thought that this game was just going to be a way for 40k to advertise their movie or their board games with a few ♥♥♥♥♥♥ graphics and alot of explosions. My friends, I was sadly mistaken. The amount of depth and effort put into this game is very apparent. The battlefield tactics are wonderfully designed and very balanced. The graphics and background to the worlds you explore are extremely well thought out and put together. Unlike most games, who either prioritize story telling or gameplay mechanic elements, the designers did an amazing job making both engaging and worthwhile. While you won't find hours upon hours of different gameplay in it's PvP multiplayer, it does come with a very interesting and well thought out PvE multiplayer that I personally enjoy playing with friends. Brings the glory of the Warhammer universe, the fun interactive style of the RTS genre, and the immersive graphics of the next gen engines together beautifully. Had fun, would love to see more content created for this game.   9/10

												Written: 6/6/2014Games for Windows Live Must DieThis is a brilliant, fun game. Too bad I can't access it anymore because Games for Windows Live. That horrible, festering mess is required to even play this game and if you haven't played a game infected with GFWL's poison in a while you will find: 1) You have to go through some procedure to recover your stupid GFWL account, once you do that you will be asked to UPDATE GFWL but 2) the in-game GFWL updater won't work, in fact, it might even hang during the update because ♥♥♥♥ you3) a manual update requires you to download Windows Live Marketplace (not Games for Windows Live because Microsoft tried to rebrand their ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ as pigshit at some point)4) in order to install Windows Live Market place, you have to first install Windows live id sign in assistant, which won't install. ...in other words TRYING TO INSTALL THIS GAME IN IT'S CURRENT STATE IS NOT WORTH YOUR TIMEGames for Windows Live Must DieThe good news is that apparently Relic is working on patching this game so it can actually be played, which is a good thing for a game to be.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2014
												With a improved engine and a redesign game, Dawn of War 2 take places in a slighly smaller scale from the orginal. Instead of constructing a base and pumping out marines and takes you command a small group of Space Marines as the attempt to get to the bottom of a mystery. You play a new Force Commander who is put in charge of an operations and must "hold the area" until assistance arrives in the form of a great Astartes fleet. You have no lines and while that normally bugs me in this instance its well done as you listen to your squad leaders speak amongst themselves and then look to you for orders. Good gear customization and tactics really do come into play in this game vs the original where you could just throw the book at them. Boss fights can get hairy and somtimes are stupidly difficult but with proper planning and tactics are winnable.  All and all i would say that i did enjoy this game i just wish they had included a bit more into it.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2015
												I was absolutely blown away by this game. I never expected it to live up to the first. But I have never been to delightfully wrong. If you are looking for a copy past of the first title this isn't it. It's a completely new experience and all for the best. It's less RTS and more action RPG. You take control over a small kill team of Blood Raven Marines that as you progress can mix and match to adapt to various missions. The story was as solid as could be and the game play was fluid and beautiful. I spent countless hours on this one years back. And didn't hesitate to buy it again on Steam. An absolute must for ANY 40K fan new and old and worth a test drive for players who have no idea what 40K is all about.

												Let me start with I love warhammer 40k, I paint the models and read the books like a massive neckbeard. I never got the last 2 expansions for DOW and wanted to relive the experence on steam but I saw dawn of war2 on sell and had to buy it. I wanted to like it but they changed the things that I loved about the first one.  Now it is NOT a bad game Its a bad sequel and im just kind of dissapointed with it. I wanted to build a base from the ground up and watch my army grow and kill everything in sight but instead you command a small squad....... Now I like the idea of heros but it just isnt the same. I wrote this to try to warn people to want to expect something really differant than DOW1

content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
												*Note This is from my experiences from playing the campaign.A total different type of strategy compared to Dawn of War as it narrows its gameplay to squad based tactics.I had a better experience playing this cooperatively in the campaign, as you have half of the units on the field. Insuring that you really have to stay together to survive. It can also feel somewhat repetitive as you battle, going over the same kill this boss/defend area jungle/desert/city map. But you also get a tons and tons of loot/wargear for your squads to use.Other points:- Visual wise, very flashy.- Can customise squads easily- The campaign is somewhat interesting, But you will be soon selecting missions to loot wargear than anything else. All in all, its is an OK game. Great two player co-op and good for players who are just learning the ropes of tactic RTS’s.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2014
												I don't really like RTS games because my base building somehow never worked. Of course, this was a decade ago and my coordination has gotten better. The primary reasons, though, that I tried Dawn of War 2 out was because there was no base building. This made the game very tactical and my units more valuable. I couldn't just produce more meat for the grinder without risking my important units.Oh and the story is pretty okay. Characters tend to be macho, but since I was using these characters over and over during battle, I've gotten attached to some. Even though your character, the Force Commander, never speaks, you feel like your doing something because the units ALWAYS compliment your leadership rather than their badass abilities.It's also a Wahmmer 40k game. THere's a lot of lore and what not, which makes me wonder why there hasn't been an RPG made yet.So... droning on....... It's a good game? 9/10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												I am a huge fan of the Warhammer 40,000 universe. My first exposure to this world was the original Dawn of War franchise, and I loved how they tweaked the traditional RTS style with a new squad based style.With Dawn of War 2 they did it again; the game wasn't going to adhere to standardised conventions. While never fully either an RTS or RPG, it contained the best of these elements. Think party based RPG with loot drops!The game allows you to appreaciate the Space Marine as it should be - a small squad of super human soldiers cutting its way through a multitude of enemies to achieve its objective. No hunkering behind defenses, no building a bigger army than necessary. You are dropped in the centre of the action and you have to literally carve your way through with bolter and chainsword.The story is relatively straight forward, but you will be constantly drawn back to the high paced visceral action and adrenaline rushing music. Nothing can relieve stress as effectively as dropping your assault marines on top of a cluster of enemies and making them go splash.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2016
												The game is not my favorite of all time but It is pretty good as a RTS game, the graphics could be nicer but they do not take away from the gameplay, the interface is pretty smooth and simplistic as well so that is a plus. The feature where you can trade in old gear or gear you simply do not want for extra experiance for your troops and heroes is a very nice addition to the game and helps you keep your inventory of stuff less cluttered and to level up your men faster to handle the challenges of the game. I do however wish that getting behind cover was easier with a larger squad, some troops it seems are bound to wind up in the open sometimes so a few extra points in health is nice but not vital to win the mission.I have not finished it yet but I do like the story so far and do recommend at least trying it out if there is a good sale even if you are new to RTS games.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												Relic Entertainment really outdid themselves when they came to making Dawn of War 2 and it's two expansion packs, Chaos Rising and Retribution. Simply put, I believe this to be the best strategy video game adaptation of the Warhammer 40,000 universe to date.The gameplay is best described as a hybrid of the original Dawn of War formula blended with elements from Company of Heroes. The visuals are exceptional, and stand up very well compared even with new releases. And like always with Relic, the sound and music is superb, drawing you completely into the setting and story with ease. Additionally, the two expansion packs, Chaos Rising and Retribution, add even more value to the original package, and are essential purchases if buying the game.By design, DoW2 (and expansions) is more like three games rolled into one. The Campaign mode (which can also be played co-operatively), a PvP Multiplayer mode and a Co-op Multiplayer mode known as "The Last Stand". All three components are similar in feel, but differ slightly in terms of gameplay, offering a unique experience for each game mode. The three modes are all extremely fun in their own right, and combined have provided me with years worth of entertainment.To sum up, Dawn of War 2 (plus expansions) is one of the best strategy games ever made. If the game even slightly piques your curiosity, I recommend you should buy it. You won't regret it. FOR THE EMPEROR!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 4, 2015
												I played DOW I and loved the strategy, the units and the low need for buildings. However, I don't think I enjoy DOW II as much (But I do like Last Stand). I believe it's mainly due to the map and gameplay repetition. PROS1. LoreMore Warhammer 40K lore in game. Interesting story except for the "Unknown Primarch" nonsense. No surprise that it's going to be Chaos orchestrating everything in the end.2. Less "buildy" MultiplayerNo need to play base tetris or resource farmer. Mostly combat.3. Cut ScenesVery short. Not exactly a cinematic but it's okay. I would have preferred a full 3-minute cinematic. 4. CharactersQuite interesting to see all the different characters from a. Force Commanderb. Tactical Marinec. Heavy Assaultd. Scoute. Assault Marinef. Dreadnaughtg. Librarian (Psyker)CONS1. Campaign Map and GameplaySo repetitive. Go to point A, kill the Boss. Rinse, repeat. How do I describe the monotonous feeling that I get when I can predict what I am going to do on the next map already? I know that there is going to be a few "yellow circles" telling me to attack those locations and kill everything there. I also know that I am going to kill a boss.The rare defense maps are pretty boring too. Defend the generators from being attacked. There. That sums up the defense maps.The objective is just to kill, kill, kill. No escort missions, no tech upgrades, no mixup, no buildup. I'm sorely tempted to just skip the optional missions just to create more chaos so that I can have some fun.2. "Unloading"Very long unload times. Posted in the forums, seems it's a forced save replay that happens.3. Multiplayer Unit BuildingIt takes too long to wait for sufficient resources to build a T3 unit. Even if you control ALL the resource nodes, the time required is just way too long. In a 1v1 or 3v3, you can't wait to build a full army. Don't forget that I've not even added in the upgrades on each unit.

Posted: April 10, 2015
												Best RTS Ive played in a long time...Pros:-SciFi setting.-Highly tactical: normally you got to choose 4 squads out of 6 different units, each with its own abilities.-Highly customazible: the units progression is amazing: experience - skills, armors, weapons, extras, etc.-Strategical decisions: the campaign mode requires to complete different goals that will affect the developing of your next missions, depending on the order and the amount of failures you got.-Plot: Im not a Warhammer fan, and the story was still quite entartaining.-Graphics: If you got a machine to run it, it is pretty. Otherwise, still looks good ;PCons:-Speed: The combats are supposed to be fast and brutal, but in order to have a proper tactical battle, you have to slow down your actions, go back take reinforcements, order your units, etc... otherwise you get into a chaotic quarrel with little tactical actions.That said, I'd give it 8/10. Have a blast! For the Emperor!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23
												Difficult review to write this. I loved the orginal DOW and I rememeber when DOW2 came out I was a little dissapointed by the change of game style (see how I get of with DOW 3!). This is more a squad based tactical game with some RPG elements but it eventually grew on me. It's only my second play through since I bought it on release and I've got to say I enjoyed it more than my re-run of DOW. The missions do get a bit samey when you depart from the scripted ones, they re-use the maps, a lot. But they are just so damn fun. There retreat system stops you from any catastrophic failures, I dont think I ever lost a mission. I enjoyed the customization of my squad and hero charactor. Theres just a lot more to do to keep your interest, chosing your weapons armour and payload definately gives u a more invested interest in your squad and adds to the experience.Im sure this game will suffer from bad reviews as a knock on of any fallout from DOW3 (internet nerds are relentless) but if your a warhammer fan and liked DOW and haven't tried this, then get it and stick with it. 8.5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2015
												One of the best RTS game series i have ever played, they are all good from the first to the last Warhammer game, with even a good variety between their titles.First one works as a classic RTS, with matches/single player campaigns where you build structures, gather resources conquering nodes and recruit/upgrade troops to attack your enemies's base, in order to win.Second one, this one and the Retribution, have a bit different RTS strategy in the singleplayer mode: you control squads of marines with different skills and utility, and accomplish some missions in the area where you drop in, mostly of the time requires you to kill every alien being, even if you are outnumbered, all of this with an exp system that upgrades the squad captains and item drops that improve their stats. The Retribution is the same thing, but with many more campaigns where you can play any race/faction existing in the DoW universe.Both of these games have also a co-op mode that is called The Last Stand, where you choose a unit from any race (in DoW II you need to buy the Chaos Expansion to play one race, and a DLC to play another unit in the DoW II: Retribution), team up with other 2 players and survive as many possible waves you can, using many skills to either control areas, destroy enemies, support allies, etc.And the last one, "Space Marine", is a fighting game in third person where you'll take part as a space marine in a war against the Orks and Eretics (obviously, you'll be outnumbered here too)As i said, every game of the serie is great, but for a new RTS style i suggest you trying this out, and then move on the other games to get the emperor's blessing, like i did.FOR THY EMPEROR

content:
Posted: May 23, 2015
												Dlc policy is a piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥but other then that its worth your time if you liked dawn of war 1. 7/10But i suspose since this is a review i will have to justify my 7/10 rating so here we go, while the game is basicly a simplication of dawn of war 1 it has its moments now i know your thinking "but why is it simplifed" well base building is gone, resources are gone so theres no points to capture other then the reinforment points, but besides that the game at its core is still dawn of war the combat is engaging and fun so they did their job on that another thing to point out is that missions can be done quickly however to counteract that you can capture optional points which gives you benifits like extra experince when finishing a mission, the abillty to place down sentry turrets and bomboardments, now lets get onto the main point on why i gave it a 7/10 because from my review most of you are thinking i'm having a lot of fun from this game (which i am) so why aren't you giving it a 10/10, well to answer that question this game does have flaws its not a perfect game like most of this review would have you belive lets go into detail about this, well for starters late game (please note my hours do not reflect my experince with this game most of my time was spent offline due to my internet being down) is very hard if you do not know what you are doing (game was played on sergent difficuty) how you spend your stat points early game will determine how hard the game will be late game if you spent your points mindlessly like i did the game will become extermely difficult, but other then that this game does its job well providing an rts experince while the core is the same as dawn of war 1 it innovates enough to consider your money and time.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
Review For Warhammer® 40,000™: Dawn of War® IIReview by: DEHUPros :- Great Story- New Gameplay- A Good Expansion.Cons :- 4 hero units for one person is hard without playing Co-op- A Bad ExpansionReview :Warhammer 40.000: Dawn of War II is a sequel to Warhammer 40.000: Dawn of War, and gives you a new story, with new Characters. The Commander have no real name, only the name you give him.It starts out with the war against Orcs and Elders, but you will face a greater thread, The tyranids.The Tyranids are a dinosaur like alien race, with the strategy; Numbers over Strength.You control only Hero units in the story, The Commander, Tarkus (Normal Marine with 4 in squad), Cyrus(Scout/Sniper with 3 in squad), Avitus(Heavy Weapon with 3 is squad), Thaddeus(Melee Jetpack with 4 in squad) and Gordian(Support). You play as the Blood Ravens in a war to free the world from The Tyranids and with equipment you can find in the stages and equip after the battle gives the game more depth and with level up system and skill tree, you can make the ultimate team.The Chaos Rising Expansion, follows up after the war on Tyranids and put you against the Chaos Space Marines.There is also Retribution. The worse Expansion ever.You can choose what race you want to play, in the campaign, but the battles are the same, only different Rival.Warhammer 40.000: Dawn of War II is a pretty well made game with pretty good story, and with the different gamemodes it makes it more fun.Additional Infomation :Developer:  TRelic EntertainmentPublisher: THQ (Former), Sega (Present)Genre:  Action, RPG, RTSReleased on Steam: 19. feb 2009If you liked this Review, please follow my Curator page :http://store.steampowered.com/curator/6858371/This review is written for :The Panda's Corner

content:
Posted: February 20, 2016
												As a lover of strategy games, I have to say this game is quite a blast (and refreshing for those who are used to base-building strategy games).This was my first time playing it so I think I will bother to describe my experience from the very beggining.First, the campaign, the characters have base personalities and they don't strave from them, instead they develop while you advance in the game, side missions are not just side missions, since characters themselves give it some thought and weight after you complete it.The gameplay is fun, quick and easy to catch up with, it's nothing complicated, you can take your time to complete missions, capture important buildings and wipe everyone out, or take the easy way out and blast your guns through hordes of enemies right to the objective. The game rewards you for not having your teammates defeated in the whole mission (they can be revived), the amount of enemies downed and the time you took to complete said mission.The upgrade system is fairly understandable, it could be your usual MMO if it wasn't because even though stats don't increase much, they still matter in battle, and special abilities unlocked while you level up help turn the tides on battles that you wouldn't even dream of accomplishing without said abilities.The Last Stand? Well, now that's a fun thing, I haven't catched the hang of it (seriously, first 3 times playing it and I got squashed in them all, except for one with a level 20 guy), but I'm getting there. The gamemode itself is interesting albeit challenging, and it can be fun if you have people who can play correctly, and are up to flaws. It just boils down to tolerance, but, that gamemode, no questions asked, is extremely fun.I haven't tried multiplayer, but I have high expectations.I would *absolutely* buy this game if I had the money, it's amazing.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 20, 2016
												As a lover of strategy games, I have to say this game is quite a blast (and refreshing for those who are used to base-building strategy games).This was my first time playing it so I think I will bother to describe my experience from the very beggining.First, the campaign, the characters have base personalities and they don't strave from them, instead they develop while you advance in the game, side missions are not just side missions, since characters themselves give it some thought and weight after you complete it.The gameplay is fun, quick and easy to catch up with, it's nothing complicated, you can take your time to complete missions, capture important buildings and wipe everyone out, or take the easy way out and blast your guns through hordes of enemies right to the objective. The game rewards you for not having your teammates defeated in the whole mission (they can be revived), the amount of enemies downed and the time you took to complete said mission.The upgrade system is fairly understandable, it could be your usual MMO if it wasn't because even though stats don't increase much, they still matter in battle, and special abilities unlocked while you level up help turn the tides on battles that you wouldn't even dream of accomplishing without said abilities.The Last Stand? Well, now that's a fun thing, I haven't catched the hang of it (seriously, first 3 times playing it and I got squashed in them all, except for one with a level 20 guy), but I'm getting there. The gamemode itself is interesting albeit challenging, and it can be fun if you have people who can play correctly, and are up to flaws. It just boils down to tolerance, but, that gamemode, no questions asked, is extremely fun.I haven't tried multiplayer, but I have high expectations.I would *absolutely* buy this game if I had the money, it's amazing.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
Review For Warhammer® 40,000™: Dawn of War® IIReview by: DEHUPros :- Great Story- New Gameplay- A Good Expansion.Cons :- 4 hero units for one person is hard without playing Co-op- A Bad ExpansionReview :Warhammer 40.000: Dawn of War II is a sequel to Warhammer 40.000: Dawn of War, and gives you a new story, with new Characters. The Commander have no real name, only the name you give him.It starts out with the war against Orcs and Elders, but you will face a greater thread, The tyranids.The Tyranids are a dinosaur like alien race, with the strategy; Numbers over Strength.You control only Hero units in the story, The Commander, Tarkus (Normal Marine with 4 in squad), Cyrus(Scout/Sniper with 3 in squad), Avitus(Heavy Weapon with 3 is squad), Thaddeus(Melee Jetpack with 4 in squad) and Gordian(Support). You play as the Blood Ravens in a war to free the world from The Tyranids and with equipment you can find in the stages and equip after the battle gives the game more depth and with level up system and skill tree, you can make the ultimate team.The Chaos Rising Expansion, follows up after the war on Tyranids and put you against the Chaos Space Marines.There is also Retribution. The worse Expansion ever.You can choose what race you want to play, in the campaign, but the battles are the same, only different Rival.Warhammer 40.000: Dawn of War II is a pretty well made game with pretty good story, and with the different gamemodes it makes it more fun.Additional Infomation :Developer:  TRelic EntertainmentPublisher: THQ (Former), Sega (Present)Genre:  Action, RPG, RTSReleased on Steam: 19. feb 2009If you liked this Review, please follow my Curator page :http://store.steampowered.com/curator/6858371/This review is written for :The Panda's Corner

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												Dawn Of War II. The sequel of to DOW which in turn had about 3 expansions. If you've played the original and are coming into this blind, then be ready for a shock. This doesn't play like a traditional RST game. In fact, it plays more like a Dota style squad based managment game.If you enjoy that kind of game, you'll probably have a right old time with this. The sound design is fantastic. All the guns sounds powerful and weighty, and when someone dies, it doesn't sound good. The graphis also, are a huge step up from the rather dated visuals of the original. The story this time around isn't as memorable as the first, but a decent romp none the less. The Multiplayer still has a solid community also. However with all that said, I would reccomend skipping this one and buying 'Retribution'. It doesn't require DOWII or it's expansion to play, and includes a lot more content, and a better story. Final thoughts: Great game, but made redudent by it's superior sequal. If you're fan of squad based, DOTA style gameplay, you might want to pic it up anyway.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2013
												Warhammer® 40,000: Dawn of War в свое время был жутко интересной стратегией, с разнообразными расами, интересными юнитами, ну и конечно же, затягивающей и эпичной кампанией. Что бы дать достойный отпор живому игроку, приходилось детально изучать понравившуюся расу, использовать сильные её качества и уметь прикрывать недостатки. В Dawn of War II от стратегии мало что осталось(тупой захват стратегических точек + убить босса), развернуться негде, да и выбор, за кого играть, теперь стал не таким уж большим, Зато графон стал очень приятен глазу, смерти - еще более жестокими(за что мы все и любим эту серию), взрывы техники тоже выглядят очень здорово. Кампания хоть и интересная, но не дотягивает до уровня первых Вархамеров. Я, как фанат серии, конечно поиграл и прошел с удовольствием игру, но сомневаюсь, что она понравится человеку, обычному любителю стратегий.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2016
												I'm a big fan of the warhammer 40k games. Loved the first game and it's expansions. I for one found this game a little odd with it's unit size and almost RPG approach compared to the first. I was reluctant to give it a go. However, i'm glad to say that i didn't.This game provides the player with an interesting and engaging story. One of which spans multiple planets and races. The characters in the game are also steller. No two characters are the same, both in aesthetics and functionallity. In terms of difficulty. The game certainlly provides the player with some level of challenge, even in the lower difficulty settings. But this can be made eaiser in online coop (Yes, this game has coop!).This game, as staited above, has online coop, which players control different units within the squad during the story mode. The game also come with two multiplayer modes. One of them being a hord style("hold them off for a long as possible") mode, and the other being a normal online competative mode.Finally. It's the Emperors will, that you purchase this game!(Also a side note. This game came with a copy of chaos rising already).

content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
												I'm am giving my honest opinion.I don't like Dawn of War II because it's an squat based game instead of Dawn of war 1 which was an building based RTS. I liked the way building used to fly from the sky crashing down to the ground ready to be build. After building a base you would create an army to fight off another army that could be from a different kind of race which also got its own abilities etc.But the point is, I hoped that Dawn of War II would be the same good game as its predecessor. but its none of the sort.  Dawn of War® II gives you an small squad putting you down a path which is making the game more story based and thus giving you less freedom in your decision making. The purpose of this was to make you feel more connected whit the protagonists. Than i thought "Why would Relic fix something that isn’t broken?". Dawn of War was a good game and a true RTS. Dawn of War II is good looking but completely different from what it should have been. The concept... completely destroyed. And i was very disappointed.

number of helpful: 8 of 15 people (53%) found this review helpful8 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 22
In the grim darkness of the far future there is only Sync Error: please restart your gameI used to play a lot of tabletop 40K, and after playing the first Dawn of War a few years ago I was looking forward to another instalment. I wish I hadn't bothered: stabbing myself in both eyes with sporks while gargling lukewarm badger diarrhea would have been a much more enjoyable and productive use of my time. Unfortunately I can't get a refund as I put more than 2 hours into Last Stand mode before finding out that the rest of the game was completely broken, so I'm leaving this review instead in the hope that nobody else will make the same mistake.When I finally got around to loading up a Private Multiplayer game, I selected game options, invited a mate to play with and the game crashed. So I tried again, and it crashed. And again, and it crashed. A trip to Google later and someone said the only way they managed to get it to work at all was by manually selecting the races of all the CPU players, as leaving any of them on random meant - you guessed it - the game crashed. Colour me stunned.When I finally got into a game, I discovered that it was basically Dawn of War I adapted for short attention spans and low IQs. Base building? Gone. Resource management? Simplified to the point of pointlessness. Variety? You get 5 races to choose from, with the rest gated off behind so many pieces of DLC it would make EA say "Hang on a minute, don't you think this is a bit of a rip-off?"I'm amused to note that apparently Dawn of War III will re-introduce some of the game mechanics that were removed. This is about as close as a game developer comes to admitting fault, but I've learned my lesson and I won't be buying it; I'll be saving my money for sporks and badger laxatives.If you value your money, your sanity or your time, stay well away from this game.

Posted: December 30, 2013
												This is the real-time strategy version of the actual wargme itself, Warhammer 40,000. It captures every detail of the action, whilst also keeping the game on a low energy consumption rate. It has many unlockable features, including 4 unlockable units, which all have their different abilities. If you enjoyed the tabletop wargame, you should buy this.NOTE: There are 2 other games that add on to this, without actually affecting the story or gameplay of the base game. Although the both games have a feature that lets you use your units from the base game.Alright, we're done here.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 8, 2011
												Have you always wanted to play real-time strategy games, but you've never been able to handle all of the details? Relic has got your back! They've done a complete 180 from the complexity of Homeworld and, whether through conscious design decisions or forgetfulness on the part of the people making the game, they've left out resource gathering, base building, the cutoff mechanic they pioneered in Company of Heroes, tech trees, control over more than a few units at once, and probably right-clicking (not sure about that last one).The end result is a game that's perfect for people who love Starcraft, but only a tiny bit, because it only requires a tiny bit of the concentration and skill that Starcraft does. Seriously you can break most of the keys off of your keyboard because you'll need like 8 to play this game.7 out of 13 SPACE MARINES.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
												Not a member of top-tier RTS games, but a sincere attempt to bring Warhammer 40K to the genre. The Dawn of War series struggles from one thing more than anything else. It's not Command and Conquer and it's not Starcraft. If you can accept that, and the extensive expansions you might need to acquire in order to play the preferred race, this game will likely keep you entertained for a number of hours. I found the campaign to be fine from a story standpoint, but often repetitive and a bit boring when it came to actual game play. The multiplayer mode was, oddly, lacking some level of immersion. The scale of the battles was quite underwhelming and while the resource acquisition was fine, the objectives were not enough to make up for an experience that was just not very... 40Kish. I can recommend this game for what it is, a 40K RTS. If you are seeking some RTS experience that immerses you for hours and really give you a new take on the genre, this really isn't the game you are looking for.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												Looking to quench that long needed online warhammer game that so many want? Here you go!Pros: Dawn of war II is a game that involves you, a force commander of the Blood Ravens space marine chapter doing things for your Chapter (Avoiding spoilers) average space marine stuff right? Wrong. The campaign is a detailed, canon, and fun experience when played alone or with up to one friend and you can never be short of a good mission in the Campaign mode. Multiplayer is largely outdated by Dawn of war II Retributions multiplayer last stand and base multiplayer. Largely due to this you wont find hardly anyone online anymore on this game in particular. Cons: Sometimes I think of myself as repeating the missions but with diffrent objectives and stuff, although the campaign is good it ends up getting repetitive after a few playthroughs this being my 4th. In co-op campaign game ending bugs on connection and during matches is common, not to mention unresponsiveness to commands. Verdict: This game is a rock on solid for anyone who loves the Warhammer 40k franchise or just likes to shoot xenos in the name of the Emperor. You will find hours of enjoyment and replayability always wondering what new wargear you can earn again and some diffrent choices mid campaign, and you would be happy with the Co-op system that allows for 1 buddy to share Cyrus, Avitus, You, Thaddeus, and Tarkus with eachother.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												Squad based strategy set in one of the most interesting sci-fi / fantasy universes you will ever come across. Unlike the first dawn of war games it isn't a true base building RTS, base building only partially comes into the game in the retribution expansion.  This is honestly one of my favorite games and along with the chaos rising expansion, the best squad based game i have come across. Although this is largely due to the awesome setting of the 40k setting. Be very careful when buying this game, it originally came with Games For Windows Live (GFWL) and doesn't work without it. The same goes for Chaos Rising unfortunately. As GFWL is now dead the game does not work (As of 1st of march 2014) and hasn't for several months.  Retribution does work but I found it to be the least interesting of the three games, the campaign involves allot of spamming units and practically no recourse management. It came across to me as some RTS squad hybrid and achieved neither. Not sure about multiplayer in it though could be good.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												I enjoy this game and recommend it for those who are looking for a non-traditional RTS game.  It plays much differently from the first Dawn of War game, which is both a positive and a large negative.  When I first played the game, I was turned off by the fact that it was not like the first game at all, where you could have massive armies facing each other, upgrade your forces, and just summon a slew of Dreadnoughts if things weren't working with your 'subtle' approach.  However, once I examined the game on its own merits, I found that I enjoyed it very much.  You have to be careful with your units and determine what their strengths are (and what you want to be their strengths).I recommend playing it, at some point, on the hardest difficulty (Primarch).  The loot is better and the strategy aspect of the game becomes much more pronounced than it does on the lower difficulties (where a suicidal assault works because you're awesome).

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 26, 2014
												Incase you can't tell from the title, Dawn of War II is a Warhammer 40,000 game. If you don't know what that is you better look it up before you think about buying something with Warhammer attached to it,  they are not for everyone .It is also a Games for Windows Live Game as well as a Steam game, so if you want a game for its' multiplayer look somewhere else. Now... I'm going to break things down into ratings.Gameplay 9/10Very strategic strategy game, tactics will get you a lot more than sheer numbers or unit strength.Single-Player Campaign 10/10The Dawn of War II campaign is a mix between Horde Survival, plot and a RTS. And I'll be damned if it doesn't do it well. Dawn of War II is quite different from its predecessors. No longer is their extensive Base Building. Infact, in a Campaign mission you have NO BASE. You may have a location, a base you need to defend for a mission but it isn't yours. You can't build stuff from it. There are strategic locations scattered around the mission maps though. Your 'army' is divided into 4 squads. Throughout the campaign you will end up acquiring more than 4 squads but you can only deploy 4 squads to a mission. Each squad is unique, they have their own strategies and skills. The game has introduced a Experience system. This system is most noticeable in the Campaign. As you kill and kill, as well as complete missions your Squads will gain levels individually (to a maximum of level 20). With each level your squads gain two points to put in a talent tree of your choice. Most squads have certain trees that they can put enormous amounts of points and skill into, while others they can only put a few in because of previously stated differences in each Squads specialization. Also, you may chose the 'wargear' for each of your squads. Some of these wargear provide statistic bonuses and similar to the squad that has that item equiped. Others are weapons that will allow the squad to better fulfill a certain task. At the end of the day though, you can have considerable flexibility with you squads. Invest you points in the right talent tree and a Squad that is intended to fulfill 1 role a certain way can fulfill a different role in a different way. Customization is one of the primary elements that has been introduced in force in Dawn of War II compared to its' predecessors. An added bonus is that the Campaign is two player, so you can play through the Campaign with a friend (who has the game obviously). From experience, doing the Campaign in co-op is loads of fun.Multiplayer 0/10The Games for Windows Live was a huge hassal, and it was not a hard decision for almost the entire active Dawn of War II playerbase to switch over to Dawn of War II : Retribution. Retribution's multiplayer is through Steam, not Games for Windows Live (thank god).Graphics 8/10There are games just as old with better graphics, but that being said... the graphics are certainly not an eyesore.Audio 9/10Outstanding voicework all around. Very realistic sounds to be heard on the battlefield. Be it the sound of the last spent shell falling onto the ground or one of you squads talking to each other on the field. Music is good.All in all, great game but I would only recommend it for Warhammer 40k fans, particularly ones who have somebody to the play the campaign in Co-Op with.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
												Not a member of top-tier RTS games, but a sincere attempt to bring Warhammer 40K to the genre. The Dawn of War series struggles from one thing more than anything else. It's not Command and Conquer and it's not Starcraft. If you can accept that, and the extensive expansions you might need to acquire in order to play the preferred race, this game will likely keep you entertained for a number of hours. I found the campaign to be fine from a story standpoint, but often repetitive and a bit boring when it came to actual game play. The multiplayer mode was, oddly, lacking some level of immersion. The scale of the battles was quite underwhelming and while the resource acquisition was fine, the objectives were not enough to make up for an experience that was just not very... 40Kish. I can recommend this game for what it is, a 40K RTS. If you are seeking some RTS experience that immerses you for hours and really give you a new take on the genre, this really isn't the game you are looking for.

												I put many highly fun hours into this game a while back. I even edited the wiki, as NEET power nerds are known to do. I never really got into the DLC that much (and holy schmidt, there's a lot of DLC now), but I remember the co-op-able campaign being a very big highlight, as well as the accessibility of the multiplayer "melee" modes. The lack of dedicated harvesting/building units makes the fights very tactical and actiony. Hero units are a lot of fun to work with, as well. Overall it's a wonderful game with a lot of polish and plenty of content (and also loads and loads of DLC).

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 12, 2016
												Really wished i hadn't WASTED my money on this thing.Ok, thats a bit harsh.Going from DOW 1 to DOW 2 is one hell of a change guys.If you want the same big scale war feel as the previous DOW games then this is probably not the game for you (unless you really *really* love strategy) - Sidenote: it seems to do strategy quite well, which is why they probably limit squad count to about... 4Sure, I didn't know what i was getting into when i bought this game but right off the bat, to me at least, micromanaging 4 small squads doesn't really scream a whole lot of 40k atmosphere to me. I'm not against micromanaging, but this game will really force it onto you whether you like it or not, and if you want to progress anywhere then you have to live with it.Again, the strategy side feels very finetuned and you can kinda tell they put a *lot* of thought into it when they were developing - but you really need to know your stuff if you're gonna beat peeps (i.e. what unit beats what, other races and their units, etc.). The game gives you a large amount of control for less units - each unit tends to have specific abilities or equipment that aid in fighting other specific units and unit types. Not bad, maybe a little overwhelming, i just simply lack the patience to play the game and learn from experience, it's almost physically and mentally painful for me to do so.Campaign drags a little but in general its fairly standard - a bit repetitve and puts a lot of focus on the individuals you control. Whether thats good or bad really depends on what kind of story you came for. It takes up a large portion of the content you pay for (unless it's a pack), but i can't say i care for it that much.personally?:Upgraded graphics -> downgraded gameplaybut you know, hey maybe thats just me

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 5
												I loved the original Dawn of War series, each expansion was great. So I was first in line for DoW II. I've been playing it a fair bit, had it before it was on Steam even (back in ye olde days of Windows Live) and no matter how much I really wish I could like it, I can't.It's boring as all Hell. It would probably be better with a friend to co-op with but honestly it's the exact same thing every mission and since you cannot build your own buildings or units there's zero variety. The story is good, the graphics are nice and that alone at least makes me want to try to get through the whole campaign and into the DLC campaigns, but it feels like such a chore because I cannot enjoy the gameplay. To add to the boring campaign missions, you must constantly return to each map you've already cleared to keep the 'threat levels' down; meaning you play the same map, the same way, several times over.The gameplay is meant to be reminiscent of Company of Heroes but it honestly falls well short of that bar. Company of Heroes was great and you had plenty to work with in terms of units and strategies. That is lacking completely here. Even the boss bottles boil down to watching for attack strikes and moving out of the way. Harder difficulties *are* hard and it just felt like I was punishing myself by playing something boring, dying and having to play it over again.I briefly attempted competitive multiplayer only to find I hadn't a clue, the game doesn't indicate what to do and the guys I was with went off in a angry frenzy, demanding that I should have gone and spent hours of YouTube research before I had the audacity to attempt online play. A game that requires study just to get the basics is no game.With DoW III coming soon, based on this miserable experience I shall definitely *not* be preordering and would only be tempted back into it if it looks more like the original series and nothing like this boring, boring, boring excuse for entertainment.

												I am running the Linux version and I think there is some things to work on. I think this game got great potential and I played it a lot during its initial release on Windows. However I got to give this a thumbs down because it seems like it never got patched and there are a couple of things that I find broken.Issues:- Does not run out of the box on some Linux distros because of bad practise when defining LD_PRELOAD_ADDITIONS- The matchmaking in the game mode The Last Stand does not work. It will detect possible games but will not match you with them. This is one of the things I remember as broken since the initial release, the time to find a game in The Last Stand. However in Linux I could leave this on for 20 minutes without finding a game, even though the game presents for me that there are games available and people to match with (this is presented by the UI).Improvements:- Options to change default keybindings. I think this is a problem with the game in general. You cannot change fundamental keybindings like the map navigation, you are stuck with the arrow keys.- No key to reset the camera angle. This is another fundamental feature that you would expect out of a game like this. If you by mistake change the camera angle you are force to either play with that angle or try to manually find that original angle.

												Something I forgot about this game. It doesn't respect your time management. Not being able to save mid-mission is a crippling deficiency for casual gamers. Can only manually back up save games. Easy mode is therefore the only enjoyable mode for me.

												they certainly did a change up after the previous games. This time instead of massive C&C like base invasions, now you are given a squad to attack with. This is more tactical and you can't just re-build people to make it less of a concern when your main character dies. number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
												Dawn of War 2 is a great game. (for simplicities sake I will include small references to the expansion Chaos rising here)If you played the original series and loved it, DoW2 is a bit of a departure from the old format but is none the less very enjoyable Overall - New mechanics, taken from Company of Heroes, such as a retreat functionMore defined rock/paper/scissorsNo more base building. In multiplayer you now have one Building from which everything is produced which you can level up through technologies advancesNew race - Tyranids (Space dinosaurs)-races available - Space Marines (super soldiers in space), Orks (they are Orks in space), Eldar (Elves in space) [chaos rising] Chaos Space Marines (Evil Super soldiers in space)Campagin - quick overviewThe campaign (in which you can only play space marines) is now a squadbased/rpg esque series of missions with different characters that you can level up/give different gear to and, in chaos rising, you can corrupt them, turning them to the ruinous powers. The campaign is fun. Missions are often 10-20 minute affairs with varying objectives. The units that you control are powerful and you will smile as 10 Space marines chew through a good 5 tyranids. The campaign is Co-op as well which is fun to play with a friend. Max level for you characters is 20 and chaos rising pushes it up to 30 and adds a couple characters.Multiplayer - quick overviewIn multiplayer, mostly you will be playing matchmaking (though im not sure how much of a community there is so you might be searching for quite a while but if you get it with friends it is still fun) with the sole objective being point control. Resources are gained through capturing requisition points much like in the original DoW. Power is now generated by holding power points and building power generators on it. The four races are all unique and fun each having their own strategies. You can level up all the different races with cosmetic details as you gain experience for games. Last stand - quick overviewLast stand is where you pick one character, which you can level up to level 20, from one of the 4(5) races (you have access to all of them no DLC unlike in retibution). Then you and 2 other people have to withstand 20 waves of enemies. A simple wave survival game mode but very fun when you get to higher waves and you have to fight 50 space marines with armour shredding plasma guns. An exceptionally fun game that i have spent far too long playing. The campaign is fun and quite long. The multiplayer is tactical and quick. Games generally don't take hours and combat can be quite intense. Last stand is a wave survival mode where you can laugh manically as you call in an orbital bombardment or fire massive balls of flame at hordes of poor gaunts.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												I have always liked the Warhammer series of games, Dawn of war 2 is the exception. I wish they follwed dawn of wars' style. Instead they went with a very boring, controller 4 units game. sure it is great for micro practice but even then it still sucks because in any RTS game i ofter and almost always command more than 4 units. the combat system is ok, its a good reminder of what it used to be. As for story line. i think all warhammer fans think the same way. kill it! it focuses on the space marines, then a latter expansion gives you a choice of race. which is cool but should have been released with the vanilla version. Nothing really pops about this game. after you do 5 missions and meet the eldar you have experienced almost everything the game has to offer, to the point where it feels to much like grinding in an RPG and less like tactical warfare. id give the game a 3/10 and a 4/10 for the latter expansion. i bet if they made a dawn of war 3 and remade the first one they would have a great game, but this... i9 wouldn't give it to anyone. even if they paid me to take it. If you want to play it i will save you some money. go find a rough brick wall, then place your face against the wall and grind your face off till you hit bone. the surgery, pain killers and wasted time in the hospital would be more fun and in the long run would be a better experience than this
