content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												Something I forgot about this game. It doesn't respect your time management. Not being able to save mid-mission is a crippling deficiency for casual gamers. Be prepared to commit 50 minutes to playing a mission, for better or worse, even if you make a crucial error. Because it's never worth rage-quitting, and it's counter-productive to play without being prepared to sink at least 50 minutes into a single mission. Not even any bug-free mods to fix this, either. Can only manually back up save games. Easy mode is therefore the only enjoyable mode for me.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 27, 2015
												Going to try and make this short...  The game is beautiful, I love how they allowed more factions than in the base game, music is nice and still has some 40k authentic this&that, but sadly it's not feeling like the glove is a good fit this time around.  Was enough of a disappointment I it led to not being able to recommend this game. I was obviously disappointed.  I will try and make this short and give a few examples, but that's it. Dawn of War was great even though it lacked full customized matches (POP, Unit limitations, in-game map maker, etc...).  I love Space Marine; love painting it, reading it and even played some Tabletop, but too many things missing that should be added or not changed from the original.  A few examples are: Unit grouping (Ctrl+# = unit made and should stay within intelligent proximity = This Technology came out many years ago and easily adjusted) and no more unique buildings ....sucks!  Their attempts to lean into a MOBA are more than obvious to disadvantage.  A moba style will kill this game for me and all I know, so hopefully they do not go that route...hopefully.  They will be hiding under the wings of many successful MOBAs.I am a diehard 40k fan/gamer and I really wanted to give this game a great review, but I just can't.  Biggest disappointment for me was simply no buildings, but we are all different and that one was mine...Sirspoony rating: 5/10 ....more buildings and a couple other major changes = 8/10I will come back again and again to check up on this game and really hope a few more patches and things will feel right once again or maybe even better, but with their obvious direction I think maybe after their MOBA fails...ugh :)UPDATED REVIEW:After some dicussion and more exploration in suggested DLC and strategy talks, my review has changed slightly.  I can now recommend this game.  When playing in a team based environment the game can be tons of fun over TS, but without that and trying to PUG, it's still lacking; given how small the community is, among other reasons.  In the end though I granted the game a better rating, but deep down inside I really wanted to find a way to give a recommendation.NEW Sirspoony Rating:  6.25/10

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
												Dawn of War 2 is a great game. (for simplicities sake I will include small references to the expansion Chaos rising here)If you played the original series and loved it, DoW2 is a bit of a departure from the old format but is none the less very enjoyable Overall - New mechanics, taken from Company of Heroes, such as a retreat functionMore defined rock/paper/scissorsNo more base building. In multiplayer you now have one Building from which everything is produced which you can level up through technologies advancesNew race - Tyranids (Space dinosaurs)-races available - Space Marines (super soldiers in space), Orks (they are Orks in space), Eldar (Elves in space) [chaos rising] Chaos Space Marines (Evil Super soldiers in space)Campagin - quick overviewThe campaign (in which you can only play space marines) is now a squadbased/rpg esque series of missions with different characters that you can level up/give different gear to and, in chaos rising, you can corrupt them, turning them to the ruinous powers. The campaign is fun. Missions are often 10-20 minute affairs with varying objectives. The units that you control are powerful and you will smile as 10 Space marines chew through a good 5 tyranids. The campaign is Co-op as well which is fun to play with a friend. Max level for you characters is 20 and chaos rising pushes it up to 30 and adds a couple characters.Multiplayer - quick overviewIn multiplayer, mostly you will be playing matchmaking (though im not sure how much of a community there is so you might be searching for quite a while but if you get it with friends it is still fun) with the sole objective being point control. Resources are gained through capturing requisition points much like in the original DoW. Power is now generated by holding power points and building power generators on it. The four races are all unique and fun each having their own strategies. You can level up all the different races with cosmetic details as you gain experience for games. Last stand - quick overviewLast stand is where you pick one character, which you can level up to level 20, from one of the 4(5) races (you have access to all of them no DLC unlike in retibution). Then you and 2 other people have to withstand 20 waves of enemies. A simple wave survival game mode but very fun when you get to higher waves and you have to fight 50 space marines with armour shredding plasma guns. An exceptionally fun game that i have spent far too long playing. The campaign is fun and quite long. The multiplayer is tactical and quick. Games generally don't take hours and combat can be quite intense. Last stand is a wave survival mode where you can laugh manically as you call in an orbital bombardment or fire massive balls of flame at hordes of poor gaunts.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2013
												they certainly did a change up after the previous games. This time instead of massive C&C like base invasions, now you are given a squad to attack with. This is more tactical and you can't just re-build people to make it less of a concern when your main character dies. Instead they fall incapacitated, but can be revived, though you have to get someone to get back their men for those in squads. I had a lot of fun with this and it felt closer to Warhammer 40K than the previous games and you could be tactical by taking up buildings or hiding behind cover for protection. Definantly worth a buy.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												I wasn't very impressed with this sequel. It felt more like a knee-jerk reaction to competition to Star Craft II than expanding on the previous game. There wasn't much "strategy" involved and it 90% of the time ended up as a really long stalemate game until someone got relaxed enough that they made a mistake. The lack of units and unit abilities like in the previous game made it very boring as well. I liked some of the "newer" units, such as heroes, but it just didn't hit the void in my heart from the first game. Being that it's a couple years later that I'm reviewing this, I can imagine that this game is no longer supported, so I doubt there will be any additions or expansions outside of what is already released for this game.Oh, and GAMES FOR WINDOWS LIVE. Why on EARTH would you include this in a game that you would sell on Steam? It's the most pain in the♥♥♥♥♥piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥and you have no other choice but to use it if you want to download updates for the game.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												Really solid tactical squad based rts with limited base building and more of am emphasis on persistent squads. The world of Warhammer 40k is shown perfectly. The game even supports co-op campaign, and online pvp/hoard modes with multiple races. (campaign can only be played as space marines) However multiplayer is pretty much dead. For a 2009 game it looks nice (same engine as Company of Heroes), but is obviously a little outdated by todays standards.Despite all this though I have to say just get DoW2: Retribution instead. This and Chaos Rising both use Games for Windows Live, an always online drm that will be shut down by July of 2014. The game is not playable offline at all. The Retribution stand alone expansion instead uses Steamworks and supports offline play** NVM, Glorious news my battle brothers! Relic has confirmed as of June 16, 2014 that they will move the servers from GFWL to Steamworks and improve the matchmaking system. The Eternal God Emperor now wholeheartedly blesses this game to anyone interested in sci-fi rts and the wonderful lore of Warhammer 40,000.The Emperor Protects

												The game is great! It's got everything an RTS should have (to me anyway) and it is great fun, there's one thing I find dissapointing about it, that is, where did the ability to build your base go? That was the best feature of DoW 1, being able to build it from just a command centre, necron monolith ect. I really miss that. I'd say that DoW 3 should really allow you to do this again, and we need all the species in the game, it just doesnt work, either we have all the species in the game or just set a few like the necron, tau, and dark eldar as dlc (though I'd not prefer it). Still this game is a great one at that, there's just a few things that makes me think the original was a bit better than this, either way, it's fun and enjoyable, so I do recommend you to get this game!

content:
Posted: October 15, 2015
												Excellent Co-op game, not so great to play soloControl a small group of Space Marines exterminating hordes of aliens in real time tactical combat. If starcraft, diablo and xcom had a three way, the result would be something like this.The story is not deep, but it is pretty well written, and the voice acting is mostly well done.In single player it can be hard to control all of your squads effectively given the fast pace of the game, but in co-op you divide the squads between the two players, which makes it much easier to get the most out of them.  Playing this game with a friend is a lot of fun.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												I wasn't very impressed with this sequel. It felt more like a knee-jerk reaction to competition to Star Craft II than expanding on the previous game. There wasn't much "strategy" involved and it 90% of the time ended up as a really long stalemate game until someone got relaxed enough that they made a mistake. The lack of units and unit abilities like in the previous game made it very boring as well. I liked some of the "newer" units, such as heroes, but it just didn't hit the void in my heart from the first game. Being that it's a couple years later that I'm reviewing this, I can imagine that this game is no longer supported, so I doubt there will be any additions or expansions outside of what is already released for this game.Oh, and GAMES FOR WINDOWS LIVE. Why on EARTH would you include this in a game that you would sell on Steam? It's the most pain in the♥♥♥♥♥piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥and you have no other choice but to use it if you want to download updates for the game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												Really solid tactical squad based rts with limited base building and more of am emphasis on persistent squads. The world of Warhammer 40k is shown perfectly. The game even supports co-op campaign, and online pvp/hoard modes with multiple races. (campaign can only be played as space marines) However multiplayer is pretty much dead. For a 2009 game it looks nice (same engine as Company of Heroes), but is obviously a little outdated by todays standards.Despite all this though I have to say just get DoW2: Retribution instead. This and Chaos Rising both use Games for Windows Live, an always online drm that will be shut down by July of 2014. The game is not playable offline at all. The Retribution stand alone expansion instead uses Steamworks and supports offline play** NVM, Glorious news my battle brothers! Relic has confirmed as of June 16, 2014 that they will move the servers from GFWL to Steamworks and improve the matchmaking system. The Eternal God Emperor now wholeheartedly blesses this game to anyone interested in sci-fi rts and the wonderful lore of Warhammer 40,000.The Emperor Protects

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19
												Coming from the original Dawn of War the new sequel builds on what made the original so immersive and engaging to play. All of what you'd expect from the warhammer universe is recreated in stunning art form and the voice acting has always been exceptional and this installment is no different. Do keep in mind though that if you are looking for the same classic sync-kill animations then this version of DOW doesn't quite have it; it has sync-kill animations, but not on the same level of detail and elaborate smoothness as the original did, which does pull me away from the immersion somewhat. Nonetheless strategy wise this is more of a micro-management RTS versus DOW 1's classic base building, with more focus on detail and unit to unit synergies. The campaign is pretty good too. As of right now, buy this when it's on sale, or wait for DOW III and get them together in a bundle.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
												I'm not too big on squad based RTSs, though this one was so fun that I couldn't put it down.  Each mission takes about ten to fifteen minutes, give or take, so you’ll be putting a lot of time into this game in order to complete the campaign.  There will also be numerous boss fights of varying difficulties to contend with.  There are two points of interest / buildings on each map that you can capture to increase your squads’ abilities, though you’ll only be able to capture one of them in a sitting.  Don’t worry, you’ll often come back to these maps (optional or not) in which case you can capture the other one you missed.  Capturing them goes a long way into making your team that much more formidable. There’s a lot more that I didn’t cover…squad types, gear slots, factions, special items, and etc.  I will say however that the game is seriously worth the money, especially now that it’s come down in price since launch.  My only complaint is the lack of variety in gear, though “Chaos Rising” offers a bit more in that department.  This is one squad management / strategy game that you won’t want to miss.---Full Review:http://www.dadsgamingaddiction.com/warhammer-40000-dawn-of-war-ii/---

content:
Posted: December 17, 2012
												Unlike other similar RTS games, this game focuses on squadron tactics combat. You don’t need to build any buildings and gather any resources in order to produce and upgrade units. By this way, you can concentrate your mind on the real-time strategic combat completely and enjoy the intense combat process. I also appreciate the RPG elements in this game. The squadrons you control can gain experience points after combat. You can allocate those points to increase many different kind of abilities. You can build your own unique tactical teams relying on your preferable tactics.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 13, 2011
												Despite the fact that THQ abandoned the original DoW2 in favor of the DLC-ridden Retribution, I still enjoy this game, and it's far superior to the first DoW. Smaller squads make for more streamlined combat, and the addition of perks and level-ups makes you want to keep your heroes alive for the next battle. And you can finally play the most vicious race in the W40K universe: the Tyranids.It's too bad players jumped ship to Retribution when it came out- it's extremely difficult to find a public DoW2 match these days, but that's not surprising considering it uses Games for Windows as a matchmaking service. Why THQ couldn't just have dropped GfWL completely from DoW2 instead of building another version is beyond me (actually, it's all about nickel-and-diming the fanbase now, so I guess it's really no surprise).DoW2 is officially my last THQ product for reasons I won't get into, but I'm glad it was this instead of one of their crappier games :).

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												This is the successor of the well aclaimed Warhammer 40000: Dawn of War franchise. If you're not a fan of the Warhammer universe or if you have not played the Dawn of War (1) series, then I do not recommend this game. The difference between this game and its predecessor is astounding. This game is consisted of a very strange mix of genres. It's a strategic RPG with more action elements than strategy. The game lacks depth, and this mix of genres might not suit all players. The graphics are improved over Dawn of War (1), and the story is fantastic, however, the gameplay is not that great. Overall opinion: good, but not great, 7.5/10

Well worth re-installing if you already have it and WELL worth the few pounds it is currently on Steam!

content:
Posted: February 20, 2016
												I have only one bad point to describe in the game. Please don't say: choose if never played rts in :recruit difficulty. I had to restart campain since I thought it was to easy even though i just randomly klicked. I now started in normal difficulty: seargant. Wich should be the one evryone should use. I felt like Nah i dont wona achieve al those achievements on such easy difficult :p . So that's why. Now for the game! -> read first if saving up for difficulty noncense Realy a fun and dynamic game even in 2016. It's more like a team based rpg fighting hordes of enemies taking cover using skills , items like nades.. etc . And u even have a nice squad that can bomb buildings while being invissible. The interactions are sweet. U can see the enemy trying to shoot u when u trow the detonation bomb to the building. Although you are invissible so they can't hit you ^^ I ended my gameplay for today againt a bossbattle. after boss missions you receive rankings on total enemies killed time and squads alive! Downside? Well you cannot replay the missions you did :( -> be aware I only played 3 hours , but it's on one day .  I feel complete after playing this ! Highly recommended . Can't wait for online play

content:
Posted: August 17, 2012
												I was skeptical when this game announced that it would only be Gears of War style combat and no strategy. The sequel to the RTS Dawn of War has been turned into an arena combat game along the lines of a MOBA. There is no resource management, no bases to construct, and no squads which are the bedrock of the table-top game on which this series is based.Admittedly, the single-player campaign has a pretty good story line, as far as game storylines go, and the art design of the Warhammer 40K universe is always great.Bottom line, if you're looking for a real-time strategy base-building game, this is not that game. If you're okay with losing those aspects, or are a real fan of the source material, then give it a try if it's under $7 USD.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2016
												Dawn of War 2 is a squad based tactical real time strategy game in which you command a small platoon of space marines, of which only about 6 of them have names and plot armor.In command of your squads you haveSilent Anime Protagonist (You)Arnold Schartzneger Big Gun McHatesImperialGuardForNoreason (he has about the IQ of a rock)Emo Edge Sniper the Hedgehog (his scout squad is absolute garbage, so no one uses him)Naive Newbie Kid made of glass commanding glass squad with health that scales really poorly even though he and his assault marines wear the same kind of armor as tac marinesBadass super captain who murdered 7 entire armies on Kronus but turns into a vegetable in a coffin because lazy writing (but he is also pretty trash and you don't get him until late, so don't even bother)and finally, Tarkus, the old bald guy and essentially the only actually alright character in the game who seems somewhat reasonable and space marine-y.Together you will fight against a not-so-unstopable tyranid threat and sometimes orks as well as some eldar who fight you also because they are socially awkward neets who are incapable of just saying "yo, nids r coming fam, if we help one another we can totes beat them" while you will essentially be reinforcing your squads with more space marines than the Blood Raven chapter physically has available.Directing your actions is Captain Gabriel "Grave News" Angelos who chimes in every now and then to tell you about grave news and him being months away from arriving to help you (when you actually beat the game in about a week's ingame time if you've played any basic RTS prior).No spoilers, but considering that you play as some space marines with plot armor it's pretty self explanatory that the good guys win in the end, I know, I was really surprised.All in all it's actually not a bad game, it has a few pretty old mods that change the campaign and MP a bit if you get bored of vanilla balancing, so it's entirely possible to have larger squads and big skirmishes and stuff if you missed those from the DOW1 series.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2015
												Unlike the first Dawn of War, DoW II's first four hours focus solely on RTS gameplay - not base-building emphasis, which I thought would be kind of nice. But 3-4 hours in, the gameplay is SO STALE. I have mostly had the same 4-5 units at my command the whole time, they aren't getting skills fast enough to keep gameplay fresh, and the tactics I'm using against the enemy are pretty much the same, regardless of which map I'm playing. The story was potentially interesting, but again, 3-4 hours in - I've stopped caring at this point. Bounce me back and forth across the universe a couple more times to do the same thing for like the tenth time.So sad that this game exists in such an otherwise incredibly lore rich setting. The Codex Astartes must classify this game as heretical material.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												This is the successor of the well aclaimed Warhammer 40000: Dawn of War franchise. If you're not a fan of the Warhammer universe or if you have not played the Dawn of War (1) series, then I do not recommend this game. The difference between this game and its predecessor is astounding. This game is consisted of a very strange mix of genres. It's a strategic RPG with more action elements than strategy. The game lacks depth, and this mix of genres might not suit all players. The graphics are improved over Dawn of War (1), and the story is fantastic, however, the gameplay is not that great. Overall opinion: good, but not great, 7.5/10

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												I honestly enjoy this game. I've heard it compared several times to a mix between RPG and MOBA and while those compariosons in the single player game are not untrue, this doesnt take away from the game. While recent issues with GFWL closing down and making the game not work for some people, relic has been working hard to fix those and for most should be able to play it. While certainly not the strategy title that puts all others to shame, what this game does deliver is:Very good graphics for an RTS gameLots of warhammer 40K goodnessA combat system that breaks the chain of resource gathering for that of squad based workCustomization of squads that lets you tailor them to your game play style while still letting them have their own very specific roles. If I had to be frank I would recomend this game to those who are trying to get into strategy games, those who like MOBAs, and anyone whos a big fan of warhammer 40K and doenst mine tromping around as the Blood Ravens. While the GFWL shut down has been a massive disiaster across teh gaming industry I'd say this game has mostly gotten out of those issues and can say that the price I spent on it was worth it. That being said if you are looking for more tradtional base building and game play closer to C&C, then give the original Dawn Of War a try. That being said, I do have a bone to pick with Relic. Guy's, if you are reading this, want to make this the RTS game that defines the Genre and destroys the competion, then you have to adress the major elephant in the room. Yeah, we both know what I'm talking about. No Space Wolf single player. And I'm not saying this as a Space Wolf fan boy. I'm saying this as a Space Wolf fanatic. Toss them in, Space vikings punching Orks. Will sell like hot cakes. We can do this guys! Make it happen!

content:
Posted: February 17
												This is a solid game, and so far a lot of fun. The people complaining and giving negative reviews are just whining that this game is very different from the first. (which is true) But you have to look at this as less of a sequel and more of an entirely unique game.This game is drastically different from DOW1, but I really like it a lot more. These campaigns and battles feel more real than in the original. Instead of building a whole new base every game (Which gets old) you just supervise the troop deployments, and command the forces you are given. Your troops are deployed from the battleships in orbit of the systems you fight on. You also get to customize your squads before battles and tinker with all thier equipment and abilities. By far my favourite thing about this game is leveling up all my squads and outfitting them before missions. It gives the squads personality, and offers unique approaches during skirmishes.All in all, ignore the whiners, they just wanted a clone of the first game with better graphics. I still play the first game now and then cause it's fun, but this is a very fresh experience too, and a load of fun.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 6, 2016
												Let us begin my puddin' cups. Like honestly I'm just writing this for my profile so you can like you know...Not read it if you don't want to. Like honestly don't read this♥♥♥♥♥♥if you don't want to, this is my♥♥♥♥♥♥ Go away if you don't like it. I don't care. No, get out!Anyways, you know it's Aylix here and today we're gonna' be looking at Warhammer® 40,000™: Dawn of War® II. Yeah I did it, that's the full ♥♥♥♥ing title. First off I'll just come right out and say it, this game is amazing. Like, you can do so much in it. And then again you can't. It's the perfect balance of limitation and freedom. I love the new formula they went for with it, it's much different from the first Dawn Of War! There's more of a tactical type of feel to it. You control a select group instead of a whole army and there's no real farming for resources or whatever you want to call it. This formula allows you to put your Commander (The guy who basically leads your little group of space marines) in cover as well as the rest of his subordinates. There is 'Good' cover and 'Bad' cover. This is indicated by dots under your character sprites. When green that means you're characters will take less or no damage at all. When yellow you're more at risk for enemy fire. There are different types of space marines you'll have command over. Each with thier own different roles. Not to spoil anything though. Well I mean it's been out for like a decade who cares. There's a group of Heavy Bolters (Heavy machine gunners) who will suppress the enemy. They take time to set up and all that. You have the commander who has leadership buffs with abilites that will help his troops. A stealth group with snipers who can sneak up on their enemies with cloak. There's the regular space marines who make up the bronze of your group. And a group of jump pack space marines who fly and and honestly just destroy everything.There are leaders for each of these small groups and you can kit them out with different weapons, buffs, abilites and armor. It's really cool and interesting. The enemies are really smart with their A.I and usually will employ tactics instead of just swarming you. You have to micro-manage all of your squads in order to get the most done in the quickest amount of time. Failing to do this will cause some of your squads to take un-needed damage. They're all a oiled team and keeping them working properly is a must.The gameplay is fluid and there are all types of enemies you can fight, different races and all of that. They are unique in their own way and use different weapons that will cause you to switch up your ways of combating other opponents. This game was really cool when it first came out and it's still very entertaining now. The multiplayer is kind of dead but it's basically, control one character and fight waves of Orks/Tyranid/Eldar. That's it. You'll probably die a lot too because most of the time you'll be playing with randoms. have fun with that! The game is rather long though, the campaign is, and it can get a little repetitive but overall if you just enjoy Warhammer and the game it's self you'll hardly notice.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 14, 2015
												Imagine the Dawn of War series, the awesome RTS game that introduced the concept of having squads instead of individual units. Now take out the RTS part of the game. That's what this is. There's little emphasis on resource gathering and an extreme emphasis on "leveling' up your units.Every race is basically copy-pasted from the last race, with a few values barely tweaked. The storyline is boring and forgettable. The campaign is a full-on RPG with literally no RTS elements. While the skirmishes have more of those elements, I'd hardly call it an RTS. Yes, you build units ocassionally, and gather some reasources, but there's no way to construct buildings on or around the resource collecting points so you just end up constantly shuffling around your army to counteract the enemy capturing your points. Most of the units can't be upgraded through buildings with passive stat increases or ability augments, you have to level them up individually.The only redeemable thing about this game and it's "expansions" (which only add extra races) is the campaign. It's different for every race (in the beginning at least) and is a marginally fun RPG adventure in which you level up your heros through-out levels and gear them up.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
												Given my die-hard love of the original Warhammer seriers, this was a kick in the balls. There are very few games of this stature that I regret buying, but this is at the top of the list. Lots of people love this game and god love 'em, but this is a change of genre that really can kill a series. I prefer the prior format, and the squad-based action doesn't appeal to me. This is the penalty I pay for not reading reviews prior to purchase. Had I know what I was getting, I never would have purchased the game. I found Command and Conquer 4 to be equally disappointing as it changed the fundamental mechanics of the game, as well. Again, shame on me for not reading the reviews. I'm happy for those who love this game, but for someone who's used to the "way things were" this really disappoints.

												Ahhhh Dawn of war. Brilliant game.What's in store for the sequel! A completely different style RTS that removes the simple army management/base building of the first game and replaces it with unit cool-down management. Imagine a single player Dota. That sounds awful doesn't it. It is. Just like Dota you also get to manage your items and stats! but not in game, you do it after each mission. Give item x to unit x. Level up tank stats on the tank character and damage stats on the damage character.Be careful if you're here because you loved the first game. This is a different kettle of fish.

content:
Posted: October 12, 2011
												This game abandons traditional RTS features such as resource management and base building (the two things I hate about RTS) and replaces them with RPG features (leveling and character customization, the two things I like about RPG).You lead a small team of about 6 heroes, and are only able to bring up to 4 into battle. You tend to be vastly outnumbered, but good use of your abilities will give you the upper hand.Co-op is where this game shines. You can give control of 1-3 of your heroes to your friend while you focus on your own. And then there's Last Stand, which I gave its own review. Last Stand in Retribution has more units and wargear, but it's still just as fun in Dawn of War II.

number of helpful: 3 of 9 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21
												1: Vanilla gameShort: If you just want to see space marines story - play easy or normal. If you want tactics game - check infested planet game, as this one doesn`t have any tactics."Cheat wherever you can. A.I.s are handicapped. They need to cheat from time to time if they're going to close the gap... Never get caught cheating. Nothing ruins the illusion of a good A.I. like seeing how they're cheating."— Jonny Ebert, lead designer of Dawn of War 2 on video game A.I.As a game this thing is just a waste of time. It is not a good tactics nor a space marines game. At least for hard difficulty. The game design is just outright heresy & the code is full of bugs. Storywise is ok (though boring). Main campaign missions don`t really pose much challenge (except for boredom) while defence missions are just impossible - i couldn`t beat any of them except for the first one, and they only become harder with squads level. Must be due to a designer have ♥♥♥♥ed up with balancing of enemy lvl to player lvl (btw leveling enemy with player is the filthiest game design mechanic). The gameplay (captain difficulty) mostly consists of "hit and run" or covert tactics, which is just a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t for a space marines game. The working tactics is - put Cyrus in infiltrate mode somewhere in flanks take Tarkus, put him in superarmour advancement mode, taunt enemies, gallop Avitus somewhere there, when imbecile AI groups together, rocket jump Cap into there. In 10 secs some squad would be instakilled, take all survivors, tap X to run back to base like ♥♥♥♥♥es (this is a space marines game, mind you), get Cyrus to raise someone in stealth mode, restore men, get back, until this group of enemies is dead. repeat. repeat. repeat for 30 hours.After acquiring the terminator armor the difficulty suddenly dropped from hardcore to rather easy.. 2: Chaos RisingWell, they made much improvements here, changing the game from bad to mediocre. My captain difficulty game was imported as primarch (or at least I got the primarch achievment after I finished it - either way that`s a bug, one of hundreds). The action is a little more dynamic, the game is a little more fun, still boring though. It is a little hard in the beginning right till the moment when I could use my 3 terminator armor sets from vanilla game, after which the game became a cakewalk. The thing that I don`t understand the most in the game design - why my units have 200-500 hp (dreadnought - around 1000), while single chaos space marine has 25000 and more? The final boss had 2.5 millions. This just makes battles tedious, not interesting.I think the best advice would be to play this game on sergeant, just to see the story, tactics-wise the game is nothing, as i said before.

Product received for free
												I'm surprised that this game has mostly positive reviews. I installed the game a few months back just started playing it, and as soon as I got to my third or fourth mission, it would no longer work the screen would go black. I hit the cache button and it got all of the data with no corruption and tried again. went to the third or fourth level and black screen again. I am not the only customer who had this issue. I tried everything to lowering the graphics a little to re-caching it to uninstalling and reinstalling it and Compatibility mode. With everything I did I'm still getting the same problem. So I guess I'll never be able to finish the story to play into Dawn Of War III, I'll just have to just skip into the third game. Thank god I got this game for free from Tremor  games.com  Also I don't know wether or not to recommend this game so I'll let you guys decide yourself. I also had to space out the website name for some reason steam or Valve won't let me say the site name whole?

												A good game no doubt, but a sequel to Dawn of War not so muchIf you want an explanation then sit tight. What Relic has done is mashed the good of Company of Heroes with the skin of Warhammer 40,000. For me personally the mechanics of Company of Heroes only suits a World War II theme, for Warhammer 40K, I think its better to remain what Space Marines was or what the previous Dawn of War games were (An actual RTS) Gone is the building, Gone is the large over powered armies, Gone are the Necrons (my favourite faction)So the game does a good campaign, the Company of Heroes mechanics seem to work well with the campaign but for skirmish, not so good in my opinion. Get if you want, but think of it as Company of Heroes 40K

content:
Posted: October 17, 2016
												Relic removed tactical pause from the game after 5 or 6 years after release. Its presence was a major point why I bought this game, and after 7 years I'm sure I couldn't get a refund, so I just removed this piece of now useless s... oftware from my game list.But about the game (not taking into account the thing above):If you liked the first Dawn of War you will like this one too, although the game mechanics changed significantly. It's still an RTS, but you'll have way less units to command at the same time. You may think that's a step backwards, but in fact the game got some RPG aspects: there's loot to be found/earn and equip on your units, and as they fight they get experience points which can be invested into abilities. Nicely done; not too simple, but at the same time you don't have to be an RPG addict to enjoy this aspect.All in all, it is recommended by all means. That's why I got furious about Relic's super♥♥♥♥♥♥move. Way to go Relic, count me out from purchasing any of your future games.

number of helpful: 22 of 51 people (43%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 16, 2015
												THIS IS NOT THE SAME KIND OF RTS LIKE THE ORIGINAL DOW. In DOW1, you would construct buildings, plan our your base and defenses, produce units to meet certain types of resistance, and work to destroy the enemy's base and take over the map. DOW2? Nope. It's a squad-based top-down shooter. I liked the original DOW because I'm a fan of Starcraft and I liked this unique take on traditional RTS games, so when I bought DOW2 thinking they just improved on the original formula, I was extremely disappointed to find that they didn't improve the original forumla, they scraped it to make an entirely new game. This would better off be marketed as a different installment to the Warhammer franchise as opposed to the sequel of Dawn of War.Is it fun? Yes, but I can't recommend it knowing that people liked DOW1 for what it was and will be expecting DOW2 to be more of that, which it isn't. This is an entirely different kind of game, and if you liked the original, you won't find more of that here.

content:
Posted: October 17, 2014
												I dont really know, how I should think about this game. While I played Dawn of War for its multiplayer, and Dark Crusade for its campaign (and multiplayer), Dawn of War 2 is like the two side of a blade.The campaign was...well...more than great, it was awesome! While you had simple unit progression in Dark Crusade, you had now the control over small squads you were able to level up, skill and equip!The campaign story itself wasnt that great sadly. The multiplayer is a desaster!Playing as the Bloodravens again, you have to defend their home system against a big horde of orcs and later tyranids.The campaign works like a round strategy game, where you equip your squads, control your planets and choose missions based on their urgency, difficulty and reward.Choosing a mission, the real game begins in RTS style and you have up to four unit groups to control. Every group is lead by a hero unit, that has special abilitys and weapons.Mostly fighting against overwelming enemy forces, you often have to fight tricky and stealthy, use good tactics and know, how to use your forces abilitys.With every mission you get XP and items and can specialize your troops on melee or ranged combat, health and ability points. You get new weapons and new equipment, and sometimes gamechanger like the terminator armor, that awesomely upgrades your troops (except the scout of course) and gave me a big wtf with the upgraded Space Marine Stormtroopers, with teleport and big hammers. Awesome!Having 4 units in every mission but a lot more usable units in your rooster, you can choose, which units you use in a mission, desiding on their abilitys and firepower and the enemys you will face.Now two things shall be said:The campaign is theoretically endless. You can play as many missions as you want. No pressure to do the final missions. You just have to hold down the enemys enough to keep the Xenos Infection low.The whole campaign is coop. Instead of 4 units, each player controls 2. Nothing more to say.Now the big bad:Beside the campaign, there wasnt really anything useful left in this game. I tried the multiplayer, but was highly disappointed. Buildings are completely gone in this game. You only have a main building and troops. Confusing, frustrating and totaly not RTS like. I played Dawn of War for a long time and I played Starcraft and Age of Empires 2 and I couldnt get any fun in the Dawn of War 2 multiplayer.I would like to give this game a good rating for its awesome campaign, but it hasnt much to offer beside it. It is like a HD version of Dawn of War without RTS gameplay. Why not making a complete Shooter out of...wait they already did that and it was awful...

number of helpful: 1 of 7 people (14%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 12
												This is going to be the most difficult game review I've had to give. This game is fun, the 40k lore is on spot. It's not like the original dawn of war games, but it's still fun (imagine the first dawn of war games, but only units, no base building).The reason this is a negative review, is because the game has technical issues that prevent newer systems from working on it.The game DOES NOT have any framerate locking. No V-synch, or anything.Why is this a problem?Because I can play this game at 4k, ultra settings, 60FPS without any issue.So much without issue, that my GPU renders 100+ frames per second.That's bad. Uncapped framerate causes high-end GPUs to spit out as many frames as possible, causing overheat and system issues (lag).On menus, my GPU is rendering 2000+ FPS (Yes, two thousand plus frames per second). It absolutely burns up my GPU.And forget Alt-tabbing to something in the background, because even in the background the game is causing your GPU to be in an endless sprint. It made my computer feel like a windows XP, 3-4 second delays between clicks outside of the game while it was in the background.After about an hour of playing, the game will stutter for 5-10 seconds, every 30 seconds.I've tried turning it down to 1080p medium settings to see if that helped, but it did not. Infact it made it worse because my GPU was cranking out thousands of FPS in-game still.I really want to play this game.But my $650 GPU is worth more than a $20 game.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2015
												By far the best RTS game ever.. I cant get enough of the campaign.. Even though i now have to reattain all the achievments again, i dont mind.. DoW2 had many, many missions, and loot.. While DoW2:Chaos Rising added the Librarian, and Choas..Every other RTS has base building, like DoW1 did.. I loved DoW1, and all the expansions, but, i hate base building, and pvp of meaningless army blobs.. I prefer the way DoW2 handles your groups.. 1 Hero, and a teammate or two..Not having the beginning of every pvp match the exact same boring BS finding minerals, building bases, etc is one of the major positives imo.. Theres no  other RTS that does this, and i pray they keep this formula for DoW3, if it ever comes.. I did NOT like DoW2 Retribution, because it went back to the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ group layouts of no name soldiers.. Not to mention, it boasts having 6 different campaigns, (1 per race) when in actuality its merely 1 campaign, played the same, from a different perspective.. Its exactly the same, 6 times.. I played each race once.. It sucked.. I cannot count how many times ive played DoW2, and DoW2:CR... Amazing! The graphics, for their time, were pretty good as well too.. And the added plus being, the horde mode(The Last Stand), which when people actually played it, was amazing.. Even added a Tau Commander, and Imperial for it.. Very fun!PS: Seems the fanboys really hate my view of base building  XDEdit: Seems DoW3 has been announced, and it looks like some colorful blizzard crap.. MOBA looking garbage, with all kinds of broken lore aspects.. Will be passing!

number of helpful: 0 of 8 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2011
												an awsome startegy game in all asppects. it's single player is really fun and is faced pased.the multiplayer is intense and has a lot of tactics. you'll need to carefully manage every single squad you have. there will never be a simple "amass lots of units of one type and crush the opponent"the grahpics and physics engine add a lot to the experience.what's great about this game as well is that you can fully enjoy it even if you have it's expansion packs. each has their own uniqe campeign and gameplay mechanic.it is very satisfying in singleplayer to lead and coordinate your 4 squads of cyborg heroes to destroy armies of alien scum, setting up your squads to cover each other right and fight the enemy from the right angle can be challanging but very rewarding.managing your special items that you have collected in each misson to power up your squads to their fullest potential is also great.the multiplayer is just as good, instead of the old fashion base building game you mainly only control units.instead of crushin the opponent's base you need to secure victory points and hold them long enough.counter each opponents units that he sends against you and learn to quickly adapt to the situation, because it will constantly change.upgrading your units in the heat of battle and deploying all of their awesome abilities makes the multiplayer frantic, chaotic but stratigic and smart none the lessa must have for either WH40K, RTS or even RPG fans...

number of helpful: 0 of 18 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												This would be a very good solo game, in fact a great solo game, if it weren't so full of bugs it makes a compost pile look barren. There is some sort of memory leak which eventually causes the video to stutter at an unplayable rate. It seldom shuts down cleanly, nor does the steam client always recover. This is likely related, as rebooting completely fixes it temporarily. There are multiple places in the various maps where troops get stuck, and without warning 25% of your team is now useless. When it happens more than once in a mission you end up unable to finish. This is all made worse because there is no way to restart a mission. The challenge of not being able to replay is great, but when the game itself is this buggy it becomes frustrating, to the point of wondering why you even bothered. I can usually overlook bugs and other problems when a game shows this much promise, but in this case the promises are empty and I have to give it a thumbs down. Which makes me sad.

content:
Posted: March 3, 2011
												Dawn of War II is a squad based strategy game with elements of Role-play. The Role play aspects are similar to Inquisitor form the 40K universe. It uses cover and angles of attack for the squad based tactics. Included is the ability to have a Battle Brother join you in the campaign. Multiplayer has two primary modes: survivor and classic RTS with flavor. Survivor mode is a Last Man standing multiplayer with 3 other players. You can choose all of the races available in Dawn of War II in both multiplayer modes.  Overall the game and storyline is enjoyable.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												What should be an entertaining tactical strategy game is marred by a litany of baffling design decisions. Single-player campaign is a slow grind through predictable groups of opponents. Doesn't do a good job of pressuring the player or making you think tactically. Whole bases will wait while you clear one building at a time. The game falls particularly short when it tries to challenge the player with RTS "bosses". These are effectively standard opponents with a huge amount of health which will cause you to spend 10-15 minutes micromanaging your troops and running in circles to kill. They don't require thought or planning, just repetitive motion while you grind through the endless health pools. Story doesn't carry the dull gameplay, either. I couldn't bring myself to finish the campaign, and that's pretty rare.The game controls are somewhere between bad and unforgivable. Entering buildings causes your squad to be deselected, so you have to reselect them to tell them to fire on an opponent. You can't leave a building without taking all of your squads out of it. Attempting to select anything without using the hotkeys will result in disaster, with your force commander usually being selected even all the way across the map. Hotkeys seem to be assigned haphazardly, with no flow between the basic commands you will issue. Expect to wave your hand wildly about the keyboard unless you customize the business. The game also arbitrarily decides when to use right click and when to use right -- you try to activate a skill and you can't move or attack with right click, but you cannot use right click to use the skill, instead being locked out of doing anything except left click to use it or hit ESC to cancel. It doesn't make sense and is really just bad UI design.There are also technical issues. If the game crashes -- and it does -- the game considers your mission a failure and drops you two "days" behind. This can also occur due to GFWL fumblings, even as GFWL is on its last legs. There's no mid-mission save for missions that can last upwards of an hour. Something comes up? Find yourself an extra hour or the game considers you to have failed the mission. You have to wait until you can find another hour until you can attempt the mission again, because progress is not saved in any way: you start all over and have to depopulate the location a second time, taking just as long as the first time. It doesn't make sense, but that's pretty much the game in a nutshell.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												One of the best RTS of its' gen. It is fast-placed, tactics oriented. If you like micro-management games like Starcraft, this may not be your cup of tea. If you prefer to focus more on your units and battlefield, than worrying about resources, bases building and who will press the X button faster to create workers/ buildings in time: Get this now.Single-Player: Great campaign, with good story even for non-Warhammer 40K fans. Nothing to do with the original Dawn of War, so it is easy to get into. Multiplayer: You get three modes. Co-op campaign, co-op PvE and competitive (PvP). The first is self-explanotary; you can play the campaign with a friend. Co-op PvE: My favourite mode, it is called "Last Stand". You basically pick a hero and fight waves of enemies, alongside with other people. It is your "arena" mode; something that we used to see in mods and maps in older RTS games -call me Starcraft, Warcraft II & III, LotR: BFME, etc etc. You have a choice of 4 unique heroes (more if you have the expansions), which you can level-up and get gear for individually. This mode is a bit like a "free" extra game that comes with DoWII. My only complain nowadays is the lack of online players.Competitive MP: Includes FFA and team-matches. The biggest cons: Not enough people online and that it still uses Game for Windows as a DRM. Due to the later, I lost my saves twice in the past...

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												I've been a fan of the Warhammer 40,000 Universe for many years now (even playing the tabletop games for a number of years). The Dawn of War Franchise has been without a doubt on of the most fun RTS series I've played, I'd fully recommend the first Dawn of War for the storyline alone, and though the subsequent games in the first series on the whole did away with such a strong narrative, the gameplay they gave was well worth the money. I'd also say to most people looking at DoW II to get the first Dawn of War just for the background which while not important at all in the second series, is just nice to have there. Now, for those who have played the first series, be prepared for a difference in game styles in relation to this. During the campaign thee is NO base building, you can't bring in new squads/vehicles throughout the game as you only have a maximum of 4 units deployed (though you can replenish loses easily enough or revive them if the squad is wiped out so that is not an issue). Even in skirmish/multiplayer the armies do not get as huge as the first game, because for example a tactical squad is only 4 men or a devastor/assualt squad only 3. However, this does not detract from the fun of the game. The maps are the perfect size, combined with the more tactical playstyle of needing to use cover and abilities well to make this downgrade in size of armies workable without issue. There is more customazation involved in this, especially during the campaign where you can upgrade your squads and specialize them, making an assault squad for example less mellee orientated but a more mobile tactical squad, and upgrade their armour and weapons through drops during missions. I'd honestly recommend any War40k fan who enjoyed DoW1 to get DoW2 if you're not sure. Even if you dont get the expansions it would be worth your time and effort. Only wait for it to be on sale as £20 for a game a few years old now is too steep and £15 at most should be its cost.

Posted: January 12, 2014
												This is the RTS that appeals to people even who don't like the generic RTS games. It has little to no basebuilding elements in the multiplayer modes and absolutely none in the campaign. This was my first game on steam and I was not disappointed; it gets to the action quickly and although it's not from a first person perspective has a lot of suspense as you may not know what's coming out of the fog of war. There is also a gamemode called the last stand, a horde mode in which you can choose and upgrade one of three characters however I would recommend retribution for this gamemode as it comes with three extra characters and a new map. Overall I would rate this game an 8/10 because it is a unique RTS but still has a few moments in which the game is insanely difficult and will screw you over if you haven't upgraded your troops properly but later installments have better versions of one of the greatest features (the last stand).

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												Dawn of War set the bar pretty high for RTS games, but DoWII took it to a new level. Rather than giving the player endlessly huge armies, it concentrates on building the characters, while still using a classic RTS-style interface. Telling the story of a desperate defense of the Aurelia sector by Space Marines who are besieged on all sides, feared by the citizens they're fighting to protect, cataclysmically outnumbered, and racing the clock, this game leads into two expansions, both of which are a blast. If you enjoy Warhammer 40K at all, you owe it to yourself to play this game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 14, 2014
												When I first started playing Dawn of War 2 I was honestly expecting a re-make of the first game series, but I was pleasantly surprised to find a game that could stand up on its own two feet. People who were familiar with the first game will remember the slightly bombastic cutscenes with in-game models and overly familiar RTS game play, and on these points DOW 2 innovates. Unlike most RTS games you're not expected to manage buildings, which is appealing. The visuals and voices also al feel well-scripted and satisfyingly re-create the chaos we've come to expect from the battlefield.However, if you're not a fan of Space Marines you'll probably be disappointed to discover the single player campaign is somewhat frustratingly geared only to this particular race. Furthermore, DOW1 actually attempted to characterise the protagonist through its cutscenes (Including a last minute plot twist that I found truly touching!) and this is where DOW 2 falls down a bit. Nobody has any real emotion aside from heroic anger or angry heroics, the Marines all talk with an irritatingly fake batman voice and the mute protagonist fails to strike any sympathy with me as a player. This is what comes of Games Workshop trying to characterise a race who are all literally clones of one another.So you'll find the meat of this game (The other 3 races!) in the multiplayer and custom game mode, and this makes for staisfying, if somewhat repetitive, fun. However you should prepare to be screwed around by EA-level connection issues as the game insists you connect to windows live even if you want to play offline, which earlier games managed to do without and adds absolutely nothing to the gameplay. I cannot fathom why anybody felt it needed this feature. Even though the game is competant in single player and multiplayer scenarios, it just can't marry the two together as seamlessly as Dark Crusade did. So yes it's a good game, but it's just not as rich with variety as Dark Crusade was. I don't see why it would have been impossible to have a DC-style campaign mode with four playable races, or even a multiplayer campaign of the same nature where multiple players fight their campaigns across a planet. So in the end it's not a terrible game, it just feels like it took away features from earlier games that worked, added features nobody wanted, and somehow makes the already characterless Space Marines feel even blander.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 25, 2012
												A unique fusion of the RPG and RTS genres, DoW II is incredible fun, shunning the Starcraft/Command & Conquer derived base-building and resource-gathering of its predecessor in favour of Diablo-style looting and levelling throughout the game's 20-some levels. Some prefer the 2004 original for its strategic elements, but I prefer DoW II as I feel it is the more interesting game, having carved out a niche all its own. The main campaign sees you play as a stoic Space Marine unit, although DoW II's excellent expansion packs have seen new campaigns introduced for several other Warhammer 40k races as well. In addition, the online play is extremely well-integrated, as one would expect from the developer of Company of Heroes. 9/10

												Surprisingly well-done multiplayer.  I feel it combines the squad based RTS with the RPG elements well-- and keeps both balanced throughout the campaign. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 10, 2014
												This is a beautiful, intense and enthralling strategy game by Relic, gameplay is very similar to Company of Heroes but focuses on a single squad of badasses (and some redshirts) getting into all sorts of violent adventures against a plethora of different types of enemies, depending on how deep your pockets are to buy the expansion packs with. This game is truly great but my only complaint is the lack of variety in the maps; here is a game designed to be milked for hours to level your squadmates and get better equipment with which to confront the increasingly difficult battles you have to face (♥♥♥♥ the missions that pit you against Eldar tanks), and you're stuck with the same handful of maps for each planet you visit, same defend the generator missions, same set pieces every time. Some randomization in the map layouts would have given this game some real staying power. I did not care for the multiplayer at all but the single-player is where it's at anyway, and it's glorious despite its flaws. Visceral, personal, condensed tactical strategy done right.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 10, 2014
												When I first played the Dawn of War II demo, I was among the groups that disliked the removal of base building and having limited squads. I refused to go further and went back to Dark Crusade.But one day the game was on sale and I thought, oh why not.And what I ended up experiencing actually was miles above what I was expecting.The removal of the bases and high Unit Pop. Actually ended up being in the game's favor for me!Sure sometimes you feel like amassing an army, but we have the other Dawn of war games to fill that void.The combat becomes very personal and requires your full management and focus. Giving a pretty intense battle. Based soley on your wits and use of the cover system and each squad's special abilities. Rather than just overpowering someone with numbers.Oh wait, we have a new race that can do that? Well there you go.The single player campaign turned out to be very enjoyable. Again the feeling of having a small loyal kick♥♥♥♥♥squad that you can put your confidence in feels very satisfying!And Last stand sweet in it's own right.My only complaint is sometimes squad AI can be derpy ever now and again. "Darn it Avitus; you're not Thaddeus!"And the DlC's are abit pricey, as you'll end up paying 3x's what you paid for to play the full game.But! Still holds up very well and I am looking foward to whatever the Warhammer 40k universe brings us...Yes even you Eternal Crusade.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Dawn of War 2 and its expanisons continue the fantastic squad driven gameplay of the first Dawn of War intruducing familiar mechanics which have been polished and refined to the dull gleam of the war filled 41st millenium. The campaign is solid and introduces an RPG like element in the way you develop your hero units and unlock new types of squad. The joint effect of boosting your hero or holding them in reserve to bolster other squads was a welcome addition allowing you to leave heros you disliked or that didn't fit your playstyle behind, without being penalised for it. Voice acting is solid with some well known names voicing distinct if overtly archetypal characters in style with the setting, and the steady progression of the plot and set pieces doesn't too often detract from the tactical gameplay that this game exceeds at.Multiplayer is truely where this game shines though, with the introduction of the last stand game mode (now a standalone puchase due to its popularity) you can drop in for a quick match with friends fighting against waves of increasingly difficult enemies and develop strateges as a group before taking your freshly leveled character in with an entirely new set of tactics and abilities. It's beauty is in its simplicity by letting you fight the well known enemies of the series on mass with only one character and your ragtag friends.More traditionally though the standard multiplayer is also much improved with easy matchmaking and fast paced fights, against human opponents the easy to manage economy shifts focus strongly onto how units and terrain are used meaning players new to the RTS genre will find it easier to start, but leaves plenty of room for more experienced players to experiment with different combinations of units and tactics with a steady metagame evolution making no one tactic the standard play.Highly recommended to all players of RTS and as a solid introduction for players branching in from other genre's who are interested to see what all the fuss is about.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 25, 2012
												The Dawn of War 2 series is the best PC adaptation so far of the Warhammer 40K tabletop game. This is a squad-based RTS. On each mission, you command 4-5 squads of Space Marines. Each squad is unique and has very different abilities. You decide which units you bring on each mission, and you spend points to level them up.Decent story, engrossing gameplay, good controls. But a word on controls. This game does not like alternate keyboard layouts (ie, Dvorak). Or rather, it does like them. Exclusively. Whatever is your default layout, that's what you're using in DoW2. So when the in-game tutorial says "Press " ; " to use this ability", you just need to know that means to hit the Z key on your standard QWERTY keyboard. Personally, that annoys the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of me.Other than that, I got no beef. This is a great game if you like RTS and particularly if you detest base-building (which only ever made sense in C&C 1 and the Dune series). While you will need to capture buildings, you will never buy or build one.A word about multi-player: No.Just don't bother. It's stupid. It's Starcraft: Warhammer edition. It's base-building and mixed-unit combat. You don't have time to strategize; you just build what you can and send it out to fight.Until you get "Retribution," which includes a magnificent multiplayer mode called "the Last Stand." In TLS, four players each choose one hero from the game's cast of characters and attempt to survive on a smallish map against infinite waves of enemies of every variety.This is some of the best multi-player action I've had in the past five years. It beats the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of Starcraft 2, and it's something that's honestly new. If it is not, please correct me.Both "expansions" change the game a lot, and I've reviewed each of them separately.DOW2 gets an A+. Seriously. This is one of the best games I've ever played. It's one of the few games that I'll ever play all the way through multiple times. I just wish I was as good at it now as I was the first time I played through.I initially put a lot of time into the tactics and I got really good at deploying and managing the troops. I don't really do that anymore. I mostly Zerg with an occassional "oh♥♥♥♥♥♥ Use a grenade!"

content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												One of my favorite games. Good story, good characters, excellent tactical gameplay. Really not much more that needs to be said for that. If you like 40k or sci-fi in general and especially if you like squad-based RTS, this is for you.Just whatever you do, don't play on higher difficulties. The game devs felt that all that was necessary to raise difficulty was massively increasing enemy stats and occasionally adding in massively overpowered enemies. Which means you'll bee going through just fine until you round a corner and there's a carnifex with more health than your entire platoon combined that can take out any of your squad leaders in 2 hits and takes virtually no damage from the best weapons they could have equipped. Or a hovertank that will quite literally wipe out a squad with each and every shot. Combine this with one of the dumbest allied AI I've ever seen ("I'm going to run up and start stabbing that enemy structure instead of the hostile units already in melee with me!" and "I'm going to run past the sword-wielding maniacs to try and enter melee with some ranged units, even though I am not a melee unit!" are two of the most common acts of idiocy) and you have a recipe for incredible frustration, especially if you're like me and you don't remember having anywhere near this much trouble just one difficulty lower. Basically, play on normal because that's when the game isn't being an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.

												Strategy games have long been about who can build the most massive number of units the fastest in order to simply overwhelm the other player. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 18, 2012
												A good game. I prefered the first Dawn of War since this one has removed the buildings side of the game (you can't build anymore during the campaign). Also, the number of squads is limited during missions. Still, all the rest is very good, with added RPG elements, with a super nice Armory that allows you to equip your troops as you wish and with a dynamically evolving campaign that gives you a selection of missions. Also, the graphics, the music, the sound are great. A major downside is that this is a Game for Windows Live (GFWL) and this single fact is the source of a ton of frustration. Imagine, I played the campaign a few months ago and now that I've changed my computer and wanted to continue, nothing has been saved online. Even if I had saved the whole folder from "My Documents", the game just wouldn't reckonise it and I had to restart all over again. But apart from that downpoint, it's worth a try for RTS fans and a must for WH40K fans. I just hope DoW3 brings back more buildings!

												When Starcraft, Warcraft and Company of Hereos had a gang bang and produces this masterpiece.When you like Starcraft and Warcraft but the gameplay mechanics are somewhat outdated.When you like Company of Heroes but wish that the theme was a futuristic fantasy.It's got factions from both Starcraft and Warcraft with the gameplay mechanics of Company of Heroes.Space Marines are basically TerransOrks are OrksEldars are basically elves or ProtossTyranid are basically the ZurgOne downside to this game is that the units in multiplayer skirmishes are really limited.But for an early game that was prdocued before Company of Heroes, it is really a next gen RTS at the time of its release.I also really like the theme of the game. There's not much RTS games using these kinds of "futuristic fantasy" themes anymore. Probably Starcraft II but hey, it's a completely different game.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2012
												A decent RPG, which relies on you keeping only a few Squads alive- you rarely control more than about 11 Marines, and then you slaughter thousands of the enemy over the course of the game, which is about 27 battles long, but you can easily squeeze it out to 40 or 50 long, which is about 40 hours- that is just single player.Also, you can customise your squads in Single Player, which means you can tailor your squads how you like- my Captain, however, is at home in combat or at range, whereas my Tactical Marines were tough as hell to hold the line, etc.Multiplayer is great, but better with friends. Game modes include:Last Stand- Play with a single Leader model with 3 other friends.Multiplayer- Team games or 1v1, 2v2, etc.Worth it for £20? Maybe. But I'd suggest the £30 deal for this and the next 2 expansions.

												This is an excellent skirmish level Real-Time Strategy (RTS) game; and if you happen to be a WH40K fan, so much the better!  Look and feel of the game is similar to Company of Heroes.  You have to capture certain strategic items on the battlefield and hold them in order to gain resources to muster up more units, there's no base building, and although the single-player campaign on features the Blood Ravens space marines, you get to play as the Eldar, Orks and Tyranids in multi-player.  It is an outstanding game!

												Heaps of fun & a really nice evolution from Dawn of War I.DoW I featured the classic "build your base & advance your units into the meat-grinder from there"-concept seen in many other Real Time Strategy games. A word of caution, do not enter this game while expecting the same as Dawn of War I.DoW II is different as it forces you to focus your efforts by presenting only a handful of units, with varying abilities to the player. Bases being virtually non-existent, you advance trough the maps with various objectives at hand, most often consisting of, but not limited to: Kicking♥♥♥♥♥

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 11, 2016
												Among my favorite Warhammer titles and favorite strategy games period, Dawn of War II is the beginning of a three-part epic tale of the battle for the Blood Ravens' recruitment worlds, continued with the Chaos Rising expansion and concluded in the stand-alone Retribution. This title reperesented a considerable departure gameplay wise from the first Dawn of War and its expansions, moving away from base building, resource gathering and large-scale battles towards a smaller squad tactics format seen in the earlier Company of Heroes series, from which Dawn of War II borrowed its graphics engine: a shift that was not universally welcomed. Dawn of War II is a blend of real-time squad tactics and an RPG loot-and-level system that I found deeply engrossing. The campaign is heavily story-driven and takes you to a variety of environments, including the interior of a space hulk made famous by the turn-based series of that name. Excellent music, visual effects and voice work accompany the proceedings. Series mainstays the Space Marines, Orks and Eldar returned, along with newcomers in the fearsome Tyranids, not featured in the first game due to, supposedly, engine limitations. Epic, pitched battles and a surprising end-game return of a popular character from the first game wrapped up the experience for me in the best way possible. The main flaw of DOW II was its use of the Games For Windows Live client, but it has since been updated to remove that particular pustule. An excellent title overall and worth playing today.
